dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lake. A forest. A dacha. A Saab outside the dacha. A light within.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DACHA- NIGHT
dialogues.text: JACK (dark, fit, mid-forties) is staring at the embers of log fire. He sips from a thick cut crystal glass of whisk The impressive US Army Special Forces crest tattooed on t shoulder of his bare torso is at odds with JACK's quiet manner and the distinguished silver that flecks his hair stubble. JACK is no longer young. A creak behind him and his eyes flick over his left shoul INGRID (34) is naked. With an intimate familiarity she ki JACK on the top of his head, sits close behind him and wr her arms around her lover, linking her slender hands acro his upper chest. Her head resting on his shoulder, her face beside his, IN and JACK watch the fire together in easy silence.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODS- MORNING
dialogues.text: INGRID leads JACK through the trees. Her coat has a white collar. They are fresh-faced and warm from bed. They head towards a vast and frozen lake. JACK senses something in the woods. Beneath the Conifers: impenetrable darkness. JACK looks around. Thick snow blankets the world and muffles any sound. Ther not the slightest breeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you looking for? Her Swedish accent is sing-song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. His anxiety is evident. INGRID laughs out loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no wolves in the woods so close to the city. JACK smiles.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LAKESIDE- MORNING
dialogues.text: They continue through the woods until they reach the shoreline of the lake. INGRID steps onto the ice. Holds out her hand. A beat. JACK takes INGRID's hand. Solid as stone, the frozen lake takes his weight. They walk out, INGRID slipping and laughing. The landscape is magical. JACK begins to relax, slipping and swearing. Suddenly, he stops. There are footprints in the thin snow going out across th lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow-hare. Beside the Snow-hare's prints are those of a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hunter? JACK studies the two sets of tracks. Those of the Snow-hare are heading out into the lake. The man's prints are heading in the opposite direction, towar the shoreline. JACK spins around in the direction they've just come from No one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, about ten metres inland from the edge of the lake, low branch dips and a thick rug of snow falls from the branch. JACK grabs INGRID, yanks her towards the cover of the lakeside trees and pushes her down into the snow. She grunts, winded. He lies besides her. We hear the CRACK of a bullet- so quiet it might be a bou snapping under the weight of winter. It isn't. JACK pulls a WALTHER PPK/S semi-automatic handgun from th pocket of his Parka. Cocks it. Waits. Then bobs up and down once. There's another CRACK from the trees. JACK pinpoints the spot from the drift of BLUE SMOKE, alm invisible in the winter air. There's someone in the shadows. He rubs snow into his woollen hat, edges up until he can see over the snow and pumps THREE SHOTS into the dusk und the trees. We hear a muttering groan and then a sliding sound, as if JACK has just shot a tobogganist. More snow slides off the trees. JACK waits. INGRID gathers her breath but loses her wits:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a gun. JACK keeps his eyes fixed on the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a gun! How do you have a gun? Why should you carry such a weapon? JACK looks at her briefly but makes no reply. She is busy thinking. So is he.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack? He stands up slowly and walks inland towards the corpse t is just visible now in the shadows beneath the trees. INGRID follows, frightened. The MAN is slouched forwards in a drift of snow, his body cushioned in white softness. JACK kicks the sole of his boot. He's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack talk to me! JACK grabs his collar and turns him over. He doesn't recognise him. JACK fumbles at his buttons and rummages in his clothing. In his breast pocket he finds a MILITARY IDENTITY PASS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hunter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not dressed like a hunter. Why is he alone? Hunters always go in pairs. For safety. Swiftly, JACK removes the bolt from the man's rifle and throws it far into the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go for help. Call the police. INGRID sets off, stumbling up the track they have made through the snow. JACK shoots her just once, in the nape of her neck. She twitches in the snow, her blood staining the white fu her coat collar. From a distance, INGRID looks like a shot Snow-hair. JACK approaches her. And steps over her, trying not to look down. Trying not to look back.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DACHA- MORNING
dialogues.text: Outside the dacha is another MAN, standing by a black Mercedes-Benz sedan. The second hunter. He is holding an automatic pistol but he's not on alert. JACK fells him easily with a bullet in the ear. He removes the clip from his WALTHER and reloads it.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DACHA- MORNING
dialogues.text: JACK packs a few belongings in a holdall.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DACHA- MORNING
dialogues.text: JACK smashes the CB radio in the Mercedes and removes the distributor cap from the engine, burying it deep in the s Then he gets into the Saab. And drives off.

dialogues.speaker: TITLES
dialogues.text: Over images of: JACK on a ferry to Gotland; changing clot and vessels for Ystad; travelling by road to Trelleborg; catching the night crossing to Travemunde; driving to Ham and from Hamburg catching a train to...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROME- DAY
dialogues.text: At a fast food stand not far from the central train stati a middle-aged man is squirting ketchup on a hotdog. It is Autumn, and without the usual mass of Summer touris LARRY stands out as an American. JACK does not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blending in? LARRY is shocked to see JACK but pretends the hot dog is centre of attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack. What brings you to Rome?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I closed the Stockholm account.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARRY might be older than JACK but he doesn't seem it. Hi demeanour is sprightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there were complications. Then LARRY turns and walks, eating carefully. He is not a who likes to get his hands dirty. JACK walks beside him. Both men keep a trained eye on their surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Collateral damage. Two shooters. Unidentified. [A beat] And a girl. LARRY takes a bite of his hot dog and casts a sideways lo at JACK. JACK is tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a bar across the street: the L'Aquila. Freshen up. Sit tight. Give me two hours.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BAR- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK washes his face in the cramped bathroom at the back the bar. In the background, on the stereo, The White Stripes cover More Cup of Coffee. JACK stares at himself in the mirror. He looks exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BAR- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK is sitting at the back of the bar. He has a good vie the whole establishment: including the entrance and the d to the bathrooms. He lights a cigarette. LARRY comes in and sits opposite him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genuinely shocked)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You started smoking again? JACK exhales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since now. The WAITER slides over and flicks a cloth at the table. WAITER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cafe? LARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Due. The WAITER disappears. A beat. LARRY puts an ENVELOPE on the table. LARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stockholm account. Final installment. JACK takes the envelope and puts it in an inside pocket. LARRY is about to speak but stops. The WAITER reappears and puts down two cups of coffee. LARRY puts two cubes of sugar in his cup and starts stirr Then speaks low and fast: LARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't stay here, Jack. You won't see `em coming, not in a big city. But you can't go far, either. If the gentlemen whose accounts you closed belonged to Brink, Gallazzo, Simenov- any of the first division- you have four or five hours at most before every airport, train station, bus stop, toll booth and ski lift from Stockholm to Skopje is under surveillance. JACK smokes. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Not a question. An acknowledgement that LARRY knows exact what he's talking about. And JACK is listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. You find a hole- somewhere nearby- and you crawl into it and you stay put until I say it's safe to come out. JACK's expression is as immoveable as a cliff face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn right outside the bar then second left. Via Spinetti. You'll find a silver Citroen C2 with Chieti plates. Check the glove box and follow the map. Castelvecchio. It's a fucking fortress. Literally. And as dead as a graveyard. Anyone within a three to five mile radius you'll see `em coming. He pushes something across the table. A MOBILE PHONE in a cellophane bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get there. Stay there. LARRY finishes his coffee and dabs at the corners of his mouth with a napkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do nothing `till you get my call.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK gets into a compact Citroen C2: nothing flash. He opens the glove compartment and finds a PLAIN MANILLA ENVELOPE. Inside the envelope is: -a PASSPORT bearing Jack's photo in the name of Edward Cl -a DRIVER'S LICENSE in the same name -and a MAP.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. AUTOSTRADA- DAY
dialogues.text: A long tunnel: one of the longest in Europe. JACK at the wheel. It seems like night: red stripes, strip lights, shadows. Vast fans suspended from the ceiling shift the traffic fu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A button of light, expanding... ...as we burst into daylight.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ITALIAN LANDSCAPE- DAY
dialogues.text: We're in another world. JACK'S CAR is winding its way up a twisting mountain road towards... ...a ramshackle, lonely, desolate Italian HILLTOP TOWN. The town sits beneath it's own castle. Medieval towers, gables, streets and church bells: framed by the snow-capp mountain peaks beyond. This is not the Italy of E.M. Forster or of Bella Tuscany This is the Italy where the Crusaders built their fortres The Italy where Sergio Leone conceived of his great Weste A CHURCH BELL tolls...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CROSS ROADS- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK stops the car. At the crossroads is a SIGNPOST pointing to the town. The sign reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK looks at the sign. He looks up at the silent town, at the vast stone rampart An OLD MAN comes out of a crooked medieval doorway, stare JACK and disappears into another building. JACK looks at the dead sockets of the windows, random ben the rotting patchwork of rooves. A DOG barks. The WIND hisses. The atmosphere is deathly. JACK makes a decision. And drives away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ITALIAN LANDSCAPE- DAY
dialogues.text: We see JACK'S CAR heading away from CASTELVECCHIO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAR crosses a spectacular VIADUCT that spans a deep RAVINE. The driver's window opens. A MOBILE PHONE in a cellophane bag is thrown out. It drops hundreds of feet down the ravine.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, MAIN SQUARE- DAY
dialogues.text: CASTEL DEL MONTE is a well preserved, happy looking littl mediaeval town with a handful of tourists. A chunk of time has passed. JACK is sitting on a table outside a small BAR wearing da glasses, sipping a coffee and reading a guide book. He lo like a tastefully dressed, well educated American tourist blends in. And no one pays him much attention as he finis his coffee, pays his bill, gets up and leaves. We follow JACK as he passes the parapet of the town rampa and looks across the spectacular valley... ...towards the deserted CASTELVECCHIO.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, OLD TOWN CENTRE- DAY
dialogues.text: At a leisurely pace, JACK passes a row of municipal rubbi bins just inside the fortified gates to the old town. Hidden well behind the bins we catch sight of JACK's park CAR.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, TOWN SQUARE- DAY
dialogues.text: We're right in the heart of the mediaeval old town: like stronghold at the centre of a castle. JACK approaches a small family run bed and breakfast just the main square. The sign reads: "PENSIONE ABRUZZO".

dialogues.speaker: INT. PENSIONE ABRUZZO- DAY
dialogues.text: The internal courtyard is refreshingly cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the centre of the courtyard is a FOUNTAIN made of marb shot through with black veins. In the fountain stands an alabaster STATUE OF A GIRL. She wearing a toga and holding a clam shell from which the wa falls. The water is delivered by a two and quarter millim diameter pipe made of bronze. As JACK crosses the courtyard he glances at the STATUE. He finds it hard to tear his eyes away.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PENSIONE ABRUZZO, JACK'S ROOM- DAY
dialogues.text: A toothbrush in the glass by the sink. The guidebook on the bedside table. Apart for this, JACK has avoided unpacking: living entire out of his holdall for some time. From the holdall, JACK produces a pair of Leica 15x56 Geo BRF Rangefinding BINOCULARS. Through his casement window he has good view of CASTELVECCHIO. He sweeps the town in grid formation: calm and methodical This is a routine assessment. JACK's POV: apart from the occasional appearance of an ol man, woman or dog, the dead town across the valley is emp

dialogues.speaker: INT. PENSIONE ABRUZZO, JACK'S ROOM- NIGHT
dialogues.text: JACK is lying on top of his bed, fully clothed and wide awake. Taped to the inside of the wooden bed frame... ...is his WALTHER semi-automatic handgun.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, OLD TOWN CENTRE- DAY
dialogues.text: Blinding SUN fills frame. JACK is ostensibly photographing the sights: the mediaeva architecture, the square, the church.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, CHURCH- DAY
dialogues.text: The CHURCH is at the top of town. A PRIEST, dressed in bl surveys the world below him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locals are going about their business, a few scattered tourists are enjoying their holiday. One `tourist' catche the PRIEST's attention. Perhaps it's his build. Or the fact that he's the only tourist on his own. Or perhaps it's the obsessive grid-li methodology with which JACK photographs the little town..

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, ALLEYWAY- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK turns casually down one of the town's many narrow alleyways. The alleyway way bends left and right in a series of blin corners and dark tunnels, the street enclosed by arches, criss-crossed by flying stone buttresses and flanked by outside stairwells. It's a stalker's heaven- or hell- depending on how dangerous the prey. JACK proceeds along the alleyway until he gets to a crossroads where FOUR NARROW ALLEYWAYS converge. Each alleyway leads uphill or downhill with varying degrees of steepness. JACK photographs each alleyway. From an upstairs window he can hear the soundtrack of a g show on television. From another alleyway comes the sound a barking dog. No dog is visible. Curious, JACK turns around, walking back the way he came. The sound of barking gets louder. On his right hand side, JACK finds a HIDDEN ARCHWAY. The HIDDEN ARCHWAY resembles an archer's slit but is big enough for a gown man to slip through. Unlike a window, t `slit' is actually just a crack in a triangular convergen of two separate and slightly overlapping ancient stone wa The confluence of two stone surfaces makes the narrow gap between them very, very difficult to spot. JACK slips though the HIDDEN ARCHWAY. Inside is a courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COURTYARD- DAY
dialogues.text: Rotting doors lead to abandoned cellars and storerooms. A MONGREL tied to a post is barking savagely, his leash keeping him inches from sinking his bared fangs into JACK JACK stares at the dog: a mysterious creature of fear and fury.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NARROW ALLEYWAY- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK reappears through the HIDDEN ARCHWAY and slips back the narrow alleyway. It's like he's materialised from thi air. He takes 2 PHOTOGRAPHS: -first of the HIDDEN ARCHWAY -and then of the street sign: VIA ROMANA. Just then a MAN on an original 1970s DUCATI turns down th alleyway and drives towards him. Casually, JACK continues walking. The DUCATI gets nearer. The MAN ON THE DUCATI is wearing black crash helmet with a tinted visor. JACK picks up his pace. The DUCATI is ten metres away. JACK's right hand moves towards his pocket. Five metres. JACK's hand goes in his pocket. Two metres.

dialogues.speaker: BANG
dialogues.text: JACK drops to his knees.

dialogues.speaker: BANG
dialogues.text: The DUCATI backfires for a second time. A pause. Still on his knees, JACK pretends to tie his right shoe l The MAN ON THE DUCATI stops outside an apartment further the alleyway, gets off his rickety motorbike and removes helmet. He's a corpulent, ruddy faced Italian man in his sixties. He glances at JACK. JACK stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buon giorno!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buon giorno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Da dove provenite?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For an instant, the directness of the question catches JA out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! L'Americano!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si. Il Americano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK's pronunciation is good but his grammar is a bit rus Perhaps he's playing up on this. It suits the role of American tourist. The MAN laughs enthusiastically emphasizing the correct grammar:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: L'Americano ! L'Americano!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN'S VOICE comes from within the house- loud and ang distracting the MAN ON THE DUCATI, who screams back passionately, enters his front door, and shuts it behind with a hearty slam. JACK walks on.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, TOWN SQUARE- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK puts some coins in a CIGARETTE MACHINE. The MACHINE takes his money but won't dispense his cigarettes. He hits the refund button but nothing happens. JACK checks the time. And thumps the machine hard. Footsteps. JACK adjusts his position and checks the time again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man behind him is reflected in the surface of JACK's battered ROLEX.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm no good with machines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK turns, smiling politely. The PRIEST smiles back. He is dressed in an ill-fitting, un-stylish black suit, a black silk stock and a deep Roman collar fraying at the e His name is FATHER BENEDETTO. He is older than JACK. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are American. This is stated matter-of-factly: like a man practising English. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You speak Italian? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poco. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Va bene! You stay at Pensione Arbruzzo. Also a statement: this time with touch of triumph. JACK is disconcerted but doesn't show it. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for much longer. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On vacation? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Working vacation. This much is true- after a fashion. They speak in English unless otherwise specified: FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lavoro? Che genere de lavoro? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Photographer. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Va bene. Che genere de fotografia? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pictures of the region. Architecture, landscapes... FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands straight and smiles winningly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No people. Sights and landmarks. For guidebooks, magazines...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! Magazine! Which magazine? JACK shows no discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually it's a syndicate. Lots of different publications. Um... Casa editrice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Va bene. So you must share a glass of wine with me. Questa sera. This evening. A beat. JACK is slightly thrown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very kind, but I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certo. You want to know the truth about Abruzzo? A priest sees everything.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PAY PHONE, CASTEL DEL MONTE- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK is using the local PAY PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea how long I've been trying to reach you? What happened to the cell I gave you? JACK speaks quietly, keeping an eye on the town square:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I forget to mention my electromagnetic hypersensitivity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get jumpy on me, Jack. That cell was secure. JACK lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a job. It's a custom fit. You don't even have to pull the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the client?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax. She triple checks out. Plus she comes to you. You don't have to move an inch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a small town, Larry. I don't like small towns. I grew up in one. Besides, I'm already attracting attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So will anyone who's trying to kill you. This is a good point. JACK lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about this. I cleaned up your shit and made you disappear. You owe me my usual twenty percent commission plus the first installment. The rest is yours. After this you're free. On JACK. Turning over the word.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FATHER BENEDETTO'S HOUSE- MAGIC HOUR
dialogues.text: The SUN is sinking behind the high mountains that overloo the hilltop town. JACK is wearing an immaculate white linen shirt. He's sitting in a small walled garden snuggled at the rea a crumbling fifteenth century edifice, overlooked yet secluded and trapping the last rays of the sun. FATHER BENEDETTO pours two large glasses of brandy from a globulous green bottle of ARMAGNAC and sniffs his drink l a honey bee hovering over a bloom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Que siamo! The quality of the brandy is good, the liquor is smooth and the glass warmed by the sun. He pronounces warmed "war-med". His English is sophistica but quaint, like an out-of-date book. JACK sniffs his drink before he sips it. Not like a connoisseur: like a White House taster checking the safet a Presidential beverage. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in ENGLISH) The only good thing to come from the Francesi, everything else... FATHER BENEDETTO grimaces. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The French are... pezzi di merda. This is not an American discovery. Italians have known this for centuries. [In ITALIAN] When Rome called France the province of Gaul, they were just the same. Arrogant sensualists. Their cuisine is fussy and their wine effeminate. Only their brandy is worthy of any attention. FATHER BENEDETTO looks at JACK. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in ENGLISH) Forgive me. I speak too fast. You study our history? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. FATHER BENEDETTO looks horrified. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come to Italy to make a guide book and you don't care about history? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take pictures, father. A beat. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. You are American. You think you can escape history. You live for the present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. JACK likes this man. His shrewdness is disconcerting but humane. JACK sips his brandy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I try to, father.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. L'AQUILA- EVENING
dialogues.text: Suburban sprawl with a mediaeval heart. L'AQUILA is the capital of the Abruzzo region and the nearest big town to Castel del Monte and Castelveccio. Like these two villages L'AQUILA is relatively isolated, nestled high up in the Appenine mountains.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. L'AQUILA, SHOPPING STREET- EVENING
dialogues.text: JACK comes out of a SUPERMARKET carrying two bags of groceries and turns quickly down a dark side street.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. L'AQUILA, VIA LAMPEDUSA- EVENING
dialogues.text: JACK passes a sign for a MODELLING AGENCY. It's a small, inconspicuous sign, but it catches his eye because its graphics are subtly lewd and it's attached to the buzzer what is otherwise a purely residential apartment block. Entering the apartment block is a beautiful twenty four y old Italian girl. CLARA. She catches JACK's eye. He walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The remnants of a simple yet sophisticated meal: apple, pecorino cheese, honey and walnuts. On his lap top, JACK has organised several weeks worth of PHOTOGRAPHS of CASTEL DEL MONTE into three categories: 1. Street plan 2. Exit routes/car 3. Exit routes/foot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he is cleaning and oiling his WALTHER PPK/S.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PENSIONE ABRUZZO, JACK'S ROOM- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK completes his morning exercises then showers and dresses. His manner is precise and methodical. Only a man has lived alone for many years can live like this. When his preparations are complete, he picks up his BINOCULARS and studies the nearby town of CASTELVECCHIO through his medieval casement window.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: The dead town has come to life! There's a MARKET in progress. The central piazza is a hiv activity. Food, local produce, clothes and cheap CD stall The market has attracted TOURISTS. Standing by a phone bo not far from a cheese stall is an attractive WOMAN in dar glasses. She's rifling through her handbag, searching for something. Under her right arm is a rolled up copy of Il Messaggero. We notice the front page of the Italian daily newspaper h been folded in half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK lowers his binoculars. Thinks. Decides to proceed with caution.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTELVECCHIO- DAY
dialogues.text: Moving through the busy market, JACK is also carrying a c of Il Messaggero... ...with the front page folded in half. He approaches the OLD WOMAN running a cheese stall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Un po' di formaggio, per favore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quale? Pecorino, parmigiano?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Questo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E un po' di pecorino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK glances casually around for the WOMAN. She's sitting outside a CAFE about twenty metres away, chatting on her cellphone. JACK pays for his cheese and approaches the cafe.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTELVECCHIO, CAFE- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK sits at an empty table next to the WOMAN. She finishes her call in English. She's well spoken. As s replaces the phone in her handbag, she knocks the newspap off her table. JACK picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grazie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prego. You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Amidst gathering clouds".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WOMAN speaks quickly, purposefully, barely looking at JACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're assuming I'm English or you'd never have mentioned the weather. In fact I'm Belgian but I went to boarding school in England. And am quite happy to converse on all subjects meteorological.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judging by her stilted choice of words this is code. A WAITER comes out and flicks a cloth over the table. It' nearly midday and the sun is hot. He speaks with a tired voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buon giorno. Desidera?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's addressing the WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Una spremute di limone. Per favore. Her Italian accent is perfect. WAITER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Signore? The WOMAN looks at JACK for the first time, studying him, awaiting his answer as if a great deal depended on it. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Una gelata alla fragola. Per favore. The final fail safe. Now they can introduce themselves: JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mathilde. The identification process over, there is nothing more to but get down to business- and conversation becomes sudden awkward. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hot. My car has no air conditioning. I asked for it, but... She trails off. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What car did they give you? Her HAZEL eyes flick over the crowd in front of the cafe. She doesn't answer. JACK clears his throat. Then says quietly: JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Range? She takes a long time to answer. When she does, she does over the rim of her half-empty coffee cup, scanning the c like a cheating wife customarily anxious not to be seen b her husband. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One fifty to one seven five meters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time? MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five seconds. Seven at the most. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Targets? MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire rate? MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rapid. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magazine capacity? MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Large. Preferably 9mm Parabellum. The WAITER delivers the Spremuta and the raspberry ice-cr The glass of lemon juice twists in MATHILDE's slender fingers. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The weapon must be fairly light. And compact. Possible to be broken down into its constituent parts. L'AMERICANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How compact? MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As compact as possible. JACK clears his throat. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a submachine gun to fit in a lady's purse? MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small vanity case would be permissible. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small briefcase would be possible. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: X-rays? Camouflage: lap-top, DVD player, MP3 or digital camera? She's not sure if he's joking or not. Neither are we. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silencer. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No such thing. You'll have to make do with a suppressor like everyone else. It'll dampen the decibels, dislocate the sound source and reduce muzzle flash. I can't make you silent but I can make you invisible as the Finnish phrase goes, but only as long as you're prepared to lose some range. JACK scans the crowd. On the other side of the square he spots a YOUNG MAN in h mid-thirties with short blonde hair and slight sunburn, hovering by a stall. Average height, slim, athletic build sunglasses, stone-washed designer jeans very neatly press with a sharp crease. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the clothes stall. Light blue shirt, open at the neck, expensive buff suede shoes. Is he with you? The YOUNG MAN has disappeared into the crowd. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't see him. In any case, I'm alone. A pause. JACK's jaw muscles grind. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can accept a slight loss of range.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a weapon with the firing capacity of a submachine gun and the range of a rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you do it? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a month. To trial. Then a week for final adjustments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is sinking. It's hunting hour. A FALCON hovers on the wind above the town, looking for p

dialogues.speaker: INT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, PENSIONE ABRUZZO- NIGHT
dialogues.text: JACK is lying on top of his bed, fully clothed but fast asleep. His eyes roll left and right beneath his lids. He's dreaming. In his right hand is a book of MEDIEVAL ITALIAN ART & ARCHITECTURE. Twitching in his sleep, JACK's grip on the ART & ARCH BOOK slowly loosens...

dialogues.speaker: THUD
dialogues.text: As the BOOK hits the floor JACK opens his eyes, sits up a rips the taped WALTHER from beneath the bed, pointing it the door. Silence. JACK's heart is beating.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PENSIONE ABRUZZO, JACK'S ROOM- MORNING
dialogues.text: JACK is looking through his BINOCULARS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...of a small yellow and blue Italian POST OFFICE VAN hea up the winding alpine road towards CASTELVECCIO.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTELVECCHIO- DAY
dialogues.text: With the market gone, the town is once more dead. And provides no cover. JACK parks his car not far from the town square, turns of the engine and gets out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTELVECCHIO, TOWN SQUARE, CAFE- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK is sitting in the CAFE where he met Mathilde. He is watching the entrance to the local POST OFFICE. He studies his WATCH. It's been an hour and no one has come or gone from the ti rural branch of the Poste Italiane. JACK puts the correct amount of change on the table and g up...

dialogues.speaker: INT. CASTELVECCHIO, POST OFFICE- DAY
dialogues.text: The shop is small and dusty. So is the POSTMASTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buon giorno. The POSTMASTER grunts his reply, jutting his chin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Il fermo posta? The POSTMASTER turns to a rack of pigeonholes behind a sa of mail hanging in a metal frame like an old person's wal aid. From one pigeonhole he draws a bundle of general delivery envelopes held together by an elastic band. Some have been there for weeks. Months even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nome? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarke. Deftly, like a teller counting through a thick wad of banknotes he flicks through the mail with thin, wasted fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarke. Una pacchetto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pacchetto!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This makes all the difference. The POSTMASTER clicks agai disappearing behind the rack of pigeon holes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarky, Clarky, Clarky. Ecco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and reappearing with a PACKAGE. The PACKAGE is from an Italian PHOTOGRAPHIC SUPPLIERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grazie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Identificazione.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK flicks his eyes downwards. He has already put his PASSPORT on the counter. The POSTMASTER scoops it up with bony fingers. Looks from the picture to JACK. JACK bears the scrutiny with a deadly straight face.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, PENSIONE ARBRUZZO- EVENING
dialogues.text: JACK unwraps the PACKAGE. He removes: -film -photographic paper -development fluids -fixing solutions Then: -a solid, monolythic rectangular receiver made out of a single piece of lightweight alloy. -a bolt assembly. -a barrel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only with this final piece is the puzzle complete. Laid out on the floor is a SOCIMI 821 SUB-MACHINE GUN. Without touching it, JACK studies the weapon like a connoisseur looking at the hue of a wine. In particular h notices that the SERIAL NUMBER has been scratched off. Then he moves slowly, assembling the weapon with precisio engineered expertise: -inserting the barrel into the front of the receiver and securing it with the nut, -opening the sidefolding tubular stock and engaging the buttpad, -snuggling the buttpad to his shoulder, -looking down the barrel, -and slowly squeezing back the finger-grooved TRIGGER as

dialogues.speaker: INT. L'AQUILA, VIA LAMPEDUSA, CLARA'S ROOM- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Our beautiful twenty four year-old Italian girl enters. CLARA. She sits on the edge of the bed, whose ageing metal sprin squeak slightly, and puts her smoking cigarette in an ash on the bedside table. She kicks off her slip-on shoes. Slips off her panties. Lifts her light cotton dress over her head and lies back the bed in one practised motion. JACK sits on the bed beside her. He doesn't look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amore? She reaches up to touch JACK as we cut to:

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, PAY PHONE- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK is scanning the town square with his usual cautiousn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your source in Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean bill of health and no OC. This was a straight favour with a dollar chaser, Jack. The guy's got a second cousin in NOCS on the graft who filched him the Socimi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you paid below the odds. The more you pay them the more cops gossip in the locker room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's gossiping, Jack. JACK watches FATHER BENEDETTO waving at him from the othe side of the square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TOWN SQUARE- DAY
dialogues.text: FATHER BENEDETTO is sitting in his API three-wheeler. This comical and endearing method of rural transportation a cross between a moped and a miniature pick-up truck. In the back of the truck are a mass of writhing SNAKES. The API is turning over but it won't start. The bonnet is open. JACK is fixing the engine. He gives a signal and FATHER BENEDETTO turns the ignition again. This time the engine starts. FATHER BENEDETTO claps and cheers.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FATHER BENEDETTO'S KITCHEN- EVENING
dialogues.text: Sixteenth century. Sombre wood panelling stained dark wit polish and smoke. Two paraffin lamps stand on a huge anti sideboard, their frosted orbs engraved with scenes from t life of Our Lord. The room is filled with a dining table: a massive black edifice of oak, five inches thick with six legs fluted li the columns of cathedrals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Using antique crockery, ancient copper pots and utensils old fashioned instruments of torture FATHER BENEDETTO performs culinary alchemy: transforming flesh into meat, dough into bread, hard earth nuggets into vegetables. He hums as he cooks: Opera arias. And Johnny Cash. JACK sips from a glass of wine and watches FATHER BENEDET potter around the wood fired stove. The priest has his ow wine which he sips as he works between bouts of humming.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FATHER BENEDETTO'S KITCHEN- EVENING
dialogues.text: JACK eats a bowl of chilled carrot and sorrel soup in silence. FATHER BENEDETTO watches him, pleased to see his guest so absorbed. As soon as JACK has finished, FATHER BENEDETTO invites hi help himself from the ancient tureen. Then he bustles over to the stove, humming again. JACK eats, studying a framed photo of FATHER BENEDETTO wi his arm around a tough, corpulent Italian man in his mid- twenties. FABIO. FATHER BENEDETTO returns to the table with a large covere dish issuing steam into his face. He notices JACK's eye-line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the sheep in my flock are dear to me, but some are dearer than most. Especially those that have strayed from the fold. Off JACK's intrigued look FATHER BENEDETTO clarifies:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fabio. He is a... [in ITALIAN] 'car doctor'. But I suspect his practice is not entirely sound. Ecco! FATHER BENEDETTO whisks the lid off the covered dish revealing a stew of poultry carcasses covered in sauce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fagiano. Pheasant. With sauce of orange juice, orange peel, chestnuts, garlic, Marsala wine and... Come si dici in Inglese? Brodo di Pollo. Chicken broth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FATHER BENEDETTO serves each of them with a complete bird pours white wine into fresh glasses. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also: salsify in garlic butter. Mange-tout. Fried wild mushrooms with truffle. JACK helps himself to vegetables. FATHER BENEDETTO watches him as he savours his first tast JACK licks his lips and sips some cold white wine. The two men regard one another, the priest awaiting a verdict. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sinful. FATHER BENEDETTO shrugs. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Holy Father eats better than this. The flash of a smile crosses the priest's face. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever wanted to be anything other than a priest? FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever wanted to be anything other than a... come se dice in Inglese...? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Photographer? FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Photographer. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do what I'm good at. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you have other talents. You have the hands of a craftsman, not an artist. You are good with machines. Yet you told me just the opposite when we first met. JACK hides his unease from the watchful priest. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Journalism cannot make you a rich man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FATHER BENEDETTO's eyes flick over the ROLEX.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you are rich already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a young man. I have my savings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in ITALIAN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My meagre income is subject to the vagaries of the stock market and with church attendance declining there's less and less money in the offertory. But if a man has God in his vaults... He looks searchingly at JACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think God is interested in me. Father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in ENGLISH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know better than to try to make a convert over pheasant and Trebbiano. JACK is silent. The two men continue eating. Then casually:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are the snakes for, father? FATHER BENEDETTO taps the end of his nose in the universa sign for secrecy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The grave soul keeps its own secrets, and takes its own punishment in silence." He has a twinkle in his eye. The priest is on a mission t extract the truth... and JACK knows it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OUTSKIRTS OF TOWN- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK is driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He checks the rear view mirror. All clear. JACK accelerates the CAR, driving it hard at the sidewalk The vehicle slams into the curb, mounting the pavement wi thump of crunching metal.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COUNTRYSIDE- DAY
dialogues.text: Just east of the old city walls a dirt track meanders downhill through a series of small holdings, allotments a scrap metal yards. The CAR moves slowly. We can hear the scrape of trailing metal. JACK pulls up beside a high chain fence. The DOGS on the other side start barking. This sets off o dogs in other scrap yards. JACK gets out of the car and approaches a makeshift hut beside the fence. Before he's a metre from the door it op and a tough, well-built, unshaven Italian man in his mid- twenties looks him up and down. FABIO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sono un amico di Padre Benedetto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suspicion gives way suddenly to warmth:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: L'Americano?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK smiles politely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buon giorno.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WORKSHOP- DAY
dialogues.text: The metal door slides open. FABIO leads JACK inside. At the back of the cluttered workshop is a blue ALFA ROME being resprayed white. Beside it, one half of a LANCIA is being welded to another. JACK knows better than to stare. He follows FABIO through to...

dialogues.speaker: INT. BACK OFFICE- DAY
dialogues.text: Girly calendars, Italian style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking pictures forty minutes north of here. Right up in the mountains. Father Benedetto said you might be able to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in ITALIAN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need models. For your photographs? Italian girls? He winks at JACK. He's being friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My publisher wouldn't stretch to a four by four and the park trails are playing havoc with my chassis. The technical English is slightly beyond FABIO's grasp. This suits JACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in ITALIAN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to take a look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. I just need something to work on a ruptured driveshaft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in ITALIAN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a mechanic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a hobby. I tinker. JACK looks at the TOOLS hanging on the walls and litterin the work benches. FABIO shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in ITALIAN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help yourself. [In ENGLISH] My garage is your garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate that. FABIO gets on with work, sliding himself beneath the resprayed Alfa Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK picks out various implements, laying them on the wor surface: drill, hacksaw, lathe, vice, mallet. Behind an oil pan with a jagged hole in it he discovers several GEAR WHEELS with the teeth sheared off. He holds biggest one up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bene? FABIO is engrossed his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si! Si! Va bene!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quant'e? FABIO grins and growls. A gearwheel with no bite is usele to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Niente! JACK wraps the gearwheel in a sheet of oily newspaper and puts it in the sports bag with the tools. At the door, he pauses. That's when JACK sees it on the notice board. A PHOTOGRAP FATHER BENEDETTO and FABIO. FABIO is much younger in this photo: fourteen or fifteen years old. He's wearing an AS football strip. Again: the priest has his arm around the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ciao. Grazie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ciao, Americano!

dialogues.speaker: INT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, CHURCH- DAY
dialogues.text: FATHER BENEDETTO rings the CHURCH BELLS for Mass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE CHURCH BELLS ringing: large, medium and small. As the CLAPPERS hit the SOUNDBOWS we smash cut to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK has laid out his newly acquired tools on the flag st floor of his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beside them is the SOCIMI SUB-MACHINE GUN. Using the CHURCH BELLS as sound cover... ...JACK puts the GEARWHEEL on a flag stone tile and smash it into five pieces with a four pound MALLET.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PENSIONE ABRUZZO- NIGHT
dialogues.text: By torchlight, JACK is fashioning CONNECTORS from the sma steel gear. It's very, very tricky work and his eyes ache in the poor light.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ITALIAN LANDSCAPE- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK is wearing a knapsack. He's crossing a MEADOW and ma his way towards a RUINED HAMLET. His manner is dark, purposeful, alert. The grass is long and the trees offer deep shade. JACK st Everywhere there is a profusion of wild flowers. His guardedness begins to evaporate. He has never seen anything so beautiful or utterly uncorrupted. He looks around, transfixed by delicate yellows and mauves, brash whites, harsh and brilliant crimsons, exquisite blues. Th air is humming with insects, bees and butterflies. JACK is transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RUINED HAMLET- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK scrambles up towards the abandoned houses, sweating the heat. His original cautiousness has returned. Carefully, he che the area for signs of recent disturbance. From the foot o the deserted hamlet he surveys the VALLEY with binoculars monitoring every square on an imaginary grid for human activity. Satisfied that he's alone, he takes a deep brea of mountain air. And scrambles back down to the valley.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODS- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK has parked his CITROEN in the shade of a squat but a WALNUT TREE. In the near distance is a LAKE. JACK crunches over half-formed walnuts until he reaches a patch of soft grass beside the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This, he decides, is the perfect spot. He unrolls a blank kneels, and from his KNAPSACK he produces: -a polystyrene cool box packed with ice and containing a chilled bottle of Frascati -a loaf of course bread -50 gms of pecorino -100 gms of proscuitto -a small jar of black olives -an orange -and a rolled blanket containing the disassembled parts o the SOCIMI SUBMACHINE GUN. JACK sets the stopwatch on his weather beaten ROLEX. It takes approximately thirty-four seconds to assemble th bastardised SOCIMI- including TELESCOPIC SIGHTS and SOUND SUPPRESSOR- and a further six seconds to press TEN ROUNDS into the magazine, slot it into the base of the hand grip snuggle the butt to his shoulder and place his eye beside rubber cup on the sight. He's fast. Carefully he surveys the lake. Settles on a CLUMP OF REED And with the focus and dexterity of a surgeon, concentrat until his grip and aim are perfectly tense and still. A beat... ...as JACK holds his breath. Then squeezes the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: CHOOP
dialogues.text: Not the conventional "phut, phut, phut" of a movie silenc but the genuine dampened sonic boom of a TAC 65 sound suppressor. Through the sight we see the water churn at four o'clock the REED CLUMP and four metres off. From the knapsack, JACK takes a watchmaker's steel-handle screwdriver and adjusts the sight, then loads another ten rounds in the magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reeds are clipped, the bullets slapping into the bank behind, mud spurting. JACK adjusts again and reloads.

dialogues.speaker: CHOOP-CHOOP-CHOOP-CHOOP-CHOOP
dialogues.text: The reed clump is shot to shit.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PENSIONE ABRUZZO- DAY
dialogues.text: The sound of CHURCH BELLS. JACK is at work: -modifying the SOUND SUPPRESSOR to make it more efficient -filing the CONNECTORS until the trigger squeeze is softe -adjusting the position of the TELESCOPIC SIGHT mountings And finally: -checking the balance of the weapon: JACK poises it on th edge of a ruler over the pencil mark he has determined to the gun's centre of gravity. The SOCIMI balances perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now the sun is low and the light fading. JACK's eyes a sore and his fingers aching. He sits on his bed with his hands on his knees, silent in dying light.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BROTHEL, VIA LAMPEDUSA- NIGHT
dialogues.text: We're in the living room of a small apartment. It's simpl and attractively furnished. There are 2 GIRLS: not obviou hookers. The FIRST GIRL is on her mobile phone. Every now and agai she glances at JACK. The SECOND GIRL approaches him for a light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E Clara qui? [Is Clara here?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Non e stasera qui. [She's not here tonight.] She loops her arm through JACK's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Volete una bevanda? [Would you like a drink?] JACK shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forse un altro tempo. [Perhaps another time.]

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE- NIGHT
dialogues.text: JACK parks in his usual hiding spot and heads for his pensione. A hundred yards ahead of him on the other side of the str is the same YOUNG MAN he spotted in Castelveccio. Cautiously, so as not to spook him, JACK continues walkin passing his pensione and heading for the town square. The YOUNG MAN is four parked cars away, leaning against a Fiat parked in front of a small pharmacy, his right hand the roof, bending over as if speaking to the car's local occupant who appears to be giving him directions. Twice he looks up and gazes along the street in both directions, casually, as if keeping an eye open for passi traffic in the narrow street. ...JACK side steps swiftly into the local bar.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BAR- DAY
dialogues.text: Crowded with locals. JACK orders a coffee. Through the window he tries to keep an surreptitious eye the YOUNG MAN. But the darkness outside throws back reflections of the bright neon-lit bar within. One reflection catches our attention. The Italian girl. CLARA. She is drinking and laughing with friends, young Italians like her. She catches sight of JACK. He turns away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE- NIGHT
dialogues.text: JACK comes out of the bar with his hand in his pocket. No sign of the YOUNG MAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slips down a side street.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SIDE STREETS- NIGHT
dialogues.text: JACK slips from one side street to another taking full advantage of short-cuts, alleyways and crumbling walls. H route is circuitous. It betrays a perfect knowledge of th maze-like back streets of the town. Eventually JACK peeps out of a tiny passageway half-way d his own street and on the opposite side of the road from PENSIONE. The entrance to the PENSIONE is clear. JACK crosses the street and slips inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PENSIONE ABRUZZO- NIGHT
dialogues.text: We're in the corridor outside JACK'S ROOM. JACK takes his right hand from his pocket. He's clutching the WALTHER. Slowly, he reaches his left hand upwards, towards the lin above the door where he finds... ...a single FEATHER.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JACK'S ROOM- NIGHT
dialogues.text: From the inside of the room we watch four sturdily fashio deadbolt locks slide open. Each lock is new and home made JACK enters, shuts the door, locks all four bolts. And si on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROADSIDE PAY PHONE- MORNING
dialogues.text: A cluster of houses by the side of a main road: a bar, a restaurant, a phone box. JACK puts a coin in the slot. Two rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got company. JACK scans the area outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's not baby-sitting the Belgian contract then he's either a Joe, a cop or a shooter. He's not with The Company, they're fast: it's been three days and no TA. He's not intel: they're deep background and he wants to be noticed. He might be a cowboy but he can't be a cop: they work in pairs and he's alone. Strike Guarda di Finanza, State Police and NOCS: he's not Italian- he doesn't look like one, dress like one or behave like one. So who the hell is he? A beat. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry? LARRY (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a long list of enemies, Jack. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he waiting for? JACK hears the sound of an engine. His hand moves to his pocket. LARRY (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack? He watches a black VW SHARON pass. There's a family insid LARRY (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to help take care of this? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can handle it. LARRY (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound spooked. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bad line. LARRY (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate the value of a pre- emptive strike in circumstances like these, I really do, but if you're going to go Generation Kill then do me a favour, OK, because I'm running out of bribe money. [A BEAT] Make it look like an accident.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TRAIN STATION- DAY
dialogues.text: Little more than a halt: one platform, one track, one sta building- locked and shuttered. JACK steps out of his car. No one around. He checks his watch: it's exactly noon. A TRAIN approaches. It's a three-carriage local. It rattles round the bend in track up the valley, diesel fumes pluming. There are no m than a dozen passengers on board. MATHILDE is the only one to alight. Her once brown hair is now BLONDE. She's wearing a light summer skirt and carrying a navy blue canvas sports bag. They shake hands as the train pulls away, belching and honking as it rattles over the girders of an iron bridge crosses some alpine rapids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Clarke. How good to see you again. Something quaint, old fashioned in her diction. English w the hint of a Belgian accent. JACK opens the boot of his car and she places her sports beside a WICKER PICNIC HAMPER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Refreshments?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Carabinieri around here like roadblocks. It's cover. She nods. They get into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the JACK's door slams we smash cut to:

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR- DAY
dialogues.text: MATHILDE's sunglasses reflect the alpine landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You picked a beautiful spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes off her shades. Her once hazel eyes are now GREY-BLUE. She glances round the hire car's drab plastic interior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would be hard pressed to make a fast get away in this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps she's nervous. Her attempt at humour isn't workin and she stumbles slightly on her grammar:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have thought you to have had at least an Alfa Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This attracts less attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up through the sun roof at the high mountains o head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK nods. She eases herself back, resigned to a long climb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train was tiring. One has to keep alert so much in cities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyelids are drooping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wake you before the turn-off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles gratefully. But does not shut her tired eyes. The CLOCK on the dash reads 12:17

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK negotiates the alpine road, leaning into the steerin wheel, shifting up or down a gear and glancing from the mirror to the road and back again MATHILDE is asleep. JACK scans her, taking in every detail: her low-heeled sh are expensive but she wears no jewelry except a Seiko wri watch on a metal strap and a thin gold chain at her throa Her tan is light, her breasts neat and her legs shapely a recently waxed. But JACK doesn't look at her like an object of desire. He looks at her cautiously, with an expression that says: "t young woman is ruthless. If she were not, she wouldn't be alive." That's when he notices the CAR in his rear view mirror. It's too far behind to decipher the make or model and it weaves in and out of frame as JACK negotiates the alpine road. MATHILDE wakes with a start. The CLOCK on the dash reads 13:05.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we nearly there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The turn-off's up ahead. His eyes flick to the rear view mirror. Hers to the wing. She spots the CAR behind. JACK catches her eye questionin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you I work alone. JACK slows just before the turn off and pulls over. Then stops. Now its MATHILDE's turn to look questioning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a precaution. He gets out of the car and pretends to urinate. The CAR behind passes at speed. A blue Seat. The driver neither slows down nor looks in t direction. JACK gets back in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And turns off up a dirt track that disappears into the meadows.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODS- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK parks his CITROEN in the shade of the squat but ampl WALNUT TREE. In the near distance is a large LAKE. This i the exact spot where he came to test the weapon. MATHILDE gets out of the car and stretches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are those houses occupied? JACK looks at the RUINED HAMLET on the hillside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derelict. I checked three days ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should check again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll check alone. There are adders the mountains. And vipers. Your shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be careful. Her voice is curt. The trust she showed him in the car is gone now.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ITALIAN LANDSCAPE- DAY
dialogues.text: They cross a meadow and make their way towards the RUINED HAMLET. The grass is long and the trees offer deep shade. JACK walks in front to ward off any snakes. Everywhere there is a profusion of wild meadow flowers. MATHILDE has never seen anything so beautiful. Overwhelme she stops. JACK stops. And watches her. She undergoes the same transformation that he did. Then she comes to, remembering herself... and walks on. Suddenly... a four foot ASP VIPER slithers across JACK's path. He claps his hands and the SNAKE writhes for cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK walks on. MATHILDE follows, pretending not to be frightened but walking closer to JACK now, scanning the l grass warily.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RUINED HAMLET- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK scrambles up towards the houses, checking the area f signs of recent disturbance. MATHILDE follows. From beside the end building JACK surveys the valley with tiny pair of binoculars, monitoring every square on the imaginary grid for human activity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have tested the gun here before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Satisfied that he's alone, he lowers his binoculars. MATH takes a deep breath of mountain air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful here. She is sitting on a loose stone wall at the edge of what once a terraced field. Her dress dips between her legs as leans forward and rests her forearms on her knees, tired the journey and the long, hot climb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish everywhere could be this tranquil. JACK looks at her, sensing a kindred spirit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be out of a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like the peace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to like something you know nothing about.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODS- DAY
dialogues.text: The WICKER PICNIC HAMPER is sitting on a rug by between t parked car and the lake. From the hamper, JACK removes: -a polystyrene cool box packed with ice and containing a chilled bottle of Aspirinio -a loaf of course bread

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -two clods of mozarella -150 gms of proscuitto -100 gms of parma ham -a large jar of pitted green olives -a Thermos of sweet black coffee -and, wrapped in cloth squares, the disassembled parts of improved SOCIMI SUBMACHINE GUN. As MATHILDE starts to assemble the weapon with easy skill JACK checks the stopwatch on his ROLEX. It takes her approximately twenty-eight seconds to assemb the bastardised gun- including TELESCOPIC SIGHTS and SOUN SUPPRESSOR- and a further three seconds to slot the empty magazine into the base of the hand grip, snuggle the butt her shoulder and place her eye beside the rubber cup on t sight. She's almost ten seconds faster than JACK. He stares at her: not an alluring young woman with good l and nice tits but an extension of the weapon itself and everything it means. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rounds? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've made up two sorts. He reaches into the PICNIC HAMPER. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty lead and thirty jacketed. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should like a hundred of each. It's an order: her voice is emotionless. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And fifty explosive. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a problem. He hands her the practise ammunition in two small cartrid boxes: the shells snug in little plastic trays. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will mercury do? She smiles almost imperceptibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercury will do very nicely. She puts the gun down butt-first, leaning it against the of the car. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have made my own targets. She reaches into her BLUE CANVAS SPORTS BAG and removes several pieces of folded cardboard strengthened with spli bamboo cane. Without speaking she sets off through the alpine blooms. her wake flutter a confetti of butterflies and grass crickets, honey bees sizzling frantically as her loose su skirt sweeps across the flowers. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch out for vipers. He keeps his voice down but she hears him nonetheless, wa with her right hand: the hand holding the AMMUNITION BOXE She's no fool. Neither is he. He has the gun. At ninety meters distance she stops beside a pile of smoo stones- a boundary cairn- overgrown with little purple trumpet blooms. She unfolds the cardboard. At this distance all we can ma out is a silver-grey shape against the stones. Returning to the car she picks up the weapon. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muzzle velocity? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least three hundred and sixty miles per hour. That's including twenty off the top for the sound suppression. Impressed, MATHILDE looks at the marks on the metal where serial number has been removed with acid. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Socimi? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight-two-one. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've not had one before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll find it easy. I've re- balanced it for the longer barrel. The fulcrum is two centimetres forward of the grip now. Which won't matter if you're firing- and I'm guessing you are- from a fixed position. No answer. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No major recoil issues. You should be able to hold onto any target. Even the smallest. MATHILDE puts two jacketed rounds into the magazine and stands with her feet apart, braced. The breeze beneath th walnut tree ruffles her summer skirt and presses it again her legs.

dialogues.speaker: CHOOP
dialogues.text: For a moment longer she holds on the target then lowers t gun, holding it under her arm like a lady on a shire hunt would hold a 12 bore. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've done a good job, Mr. Clarke. Thank you. Thank you very much. She makes a minute adjustment to the telescopic sight, wi her fingernail. She can't have turned the vertical screw than one notch. Then she fully loads and fires again.

dialogues.speaker: CHOOP-CHOOP-CHOOP
dialogues.text: JACK lifts his binoculars and looks at the target. It's t unmistakable outline of a BOEING 747-400, about one and a half metres long. Painted against the cut-out is the uptu at the end of the wing. The front doorway is shaded in. Standing in it is the SILHOUETTE OF A MAN. In the centre his head are three small HOLES. With the magazine containing the remaining 28 jacketed rounds, MATHILDE takes aim again.

dialogues.speaker: CHOOP-CHOOP-CHOOP-CHOOP
dialogues.text: Through his binoculars, JACK can see the empty space wher the target's head used to be, the scarred stones behind a the little scraps of cardboard floating on the warm air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATHILDE says nothing. She fills the magazine with lead rounds, snaps it in place and hands the weapon to JACK. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to the stones and fire near me. He's taken aback. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say... She looks round for a target. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...into the bush with the yellow flowers. Two bursts. Five seconds apart. Slowly, JACK walks down to the stones, turns and looks ba The CITROEN is well hidden in the deep shade of the walnu tree. So is MATHILDE. In the poor light all he can see is dress and her blouse. He wipes the sweat from his eyes an shuts them tightly. This is not just a weapon test... it's a test of trust. He opens his eyes again. MATHILDE turns to face him as he shoulders the weapon. He aims the SOCIMI at the YELLOW FLOWERS right beside her Holds his breath. And pulls the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: CHOOP
dialogues.text: MATHILDE remains untouched. So do the YELLOW FLOWERS. Troubled, JACK blinks rapidly and counts to five. Then he fires again.

dialogues.speaker: CHOOP
dialogues.text: Through the sight, we see two stems of YELLOW BLOSSOM fal sideways. Relieved, JACK walks slowly back to the car. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound suppression is superb. I couldn't place the direction of fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From her sports bag she removes a plain brown MANILLA ENVELOPE. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall require the rounds and the weapon by the first of next month. In the meantime would you tighten the adjusting screws on the sight, they are too loose. And lengthen the stock by three centimetres. I also want a sixty round magazine. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll upset the balance. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm prepared to accept that. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'm happy to oblige. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the a case? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A briefcase. Samsonite. Standard pattern in black with combination locks. Is there a number you'd prefer? She thinks. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight-two-one. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight-two-one. MATHILDE hands him the ENVELOPE and disassembles the weap JACK wraps the SOCIMI parts up in their cloth squares and places them in the bottom of the PICNIC HAMPER. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want done with these? She has collected up the spent CARTRIDGE CASES. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw them in the lake. She walks down to the water and hurls the brass cases in. FISH rise. Again, the beauty of the place transfixes her. By the time she turns back, JACK has laid out the picnic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How thoughtful. She picks up a bottle of wine. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know Italian wine. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aspirinio. Like Mosacata but frizzante. Deftly he uncorks a bottle. And pours it into the grass. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't look right if the picnic wasn't touched. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You chilled the wine. I thought... JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It had to be chilled. They're Italian cops. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed) You think of everything. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm paid to. Don't move. She freezes. JACK points slowly. On her tanned forearm is a BUTTERFLY. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. They both stare at the insect, transfixed. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so beautiful. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parnassius apollo. It's endangered. She looks up at him. Like it's a revelation she says: MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like coming here. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It serves its purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never taken a woman here before? JACK is momentarily taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The BUTTERFLY flits away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you do not have a woman in your life. It is not easy for us to keep relationships. Not in our world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an acquaintance. A beat. She waits for him to say more. He doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friendships are transitory. It is... Suddenly, there's movement in the bushes. JACK snatches up his BINOCULARS. MATHILDE scans the tree cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wild boar. He hands her the binoculars. And hurriedly packs up the picnic.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR- DAY
dialogues.text: Her sunglasses back on, MATHILDE watches the meadows slip backwards in the nearside wing mirror as the car bumps ba down the alpine track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you hadn't brought me here. Again... a real sadness. JACK glances at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the sort of place I wish I'd discovered by myself. Then maybe one day I could have retired here. But you already know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK is touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm much older than you. By the time you've retired I'll be dead.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RURAL TRAIN STATION- DAY
dialogues.text: The CITROEN pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CITROEN- DAY
dialogues.text: The YOUNG WOMAN's manner is once more tense and formal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will meet as before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK nods. The distant sound of a DIESEL ENGINE. The train is approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the first of next month?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around noon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even a nod this time: just a slow blink. MATHILDE opens the door, runs around to the boot and grab her canvas sports bag. Then returns to the passenger side the car and looks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for a lovely day. Mr. Butterfly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans in.. ...and kisses him lightly on the cheek, her lips light an quick on his stubble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must take your mistress to the meadow for a picnic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes the car door, walks onto the platform and vani onto a waiting carriage. The TRAIN honks and belches, mov off down the track in the direction from which it came. JACK watches it go. And drives off. Confused.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, LOCAL BAR- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Two OLD MEN drinking beer at the bar. Two more at a table playing Scopa with old fashioned Trentine playing cards. Sitting at the back of the room, JACK stares at a shot of Grappa. Above him, mounted on the wall, is a TELEVISION. On the T a Western: Charles Bronson and Henry Fonda in ONCE UPON A TIME IN THE WEST. JACK downs his shot, gets up and walks over to the bar. P The BARMAN nods at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergio Leone. Italiano. JACK turns and looks. HENRY FONDA in close-up, is about to shoot a red headed B of seven in the head. JACK stares. Just at the moment that the gun goes off... ...JACK turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in poor ENGLISH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like cow boy movie? JACK thinks. Then shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hokey.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BROTHEL, VIA LAMPEDUSA- NIGHT
