dialogues.text: CLARA and JACK are naked. JACK tries to kiss her on the lips but CLARA turns away: enough to let him know this is against the rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK kisses her neck. Her breasts. Her stomach. As he moves his head between her legs, her fingers (alrea ensnared in his hair) tighten their grip, stopping him fr going further. JACK looks up at CLARA, across her belly, and she looks b at him, her expression fixed yet curious. Against her rules but not, we sense, against her wishes, kisses CLARA softly, tenderly, deeply until she is moving against his tongue, using her sex like a mouth to kiss hi return. They make love, breaking each of Clara's two remaining ru in turn. First: JACK puts her in a position she initially resists. Then: he kisses her. CLARA comes, not wanting to. Suddenly, preoccupied, JACK does not.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BROTHEL, VIA LAMPEDUSA- NIGHT
dialogues.text: JACK is in bed with CLARA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morboso? She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with certainty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morboso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morboso?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morboso is like... when you can't stop thinking about something. He stares back at her: wordless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or someone. A long pause: her eyes searching his. JACK sits up, light cigarette and stands by the window, looking through the blind, down into the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You needn't act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Act?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARA watches him, confused but fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might have to act with your other clients but you don't have to pretend anything at all with me. She lights herself a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to be yourself with me. Be as indifferent as you like. I came here to get pleasure, not to give it. He hands her CASH. She counts it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I pretend very well. I got more tip than the other girls usually get. He walks to the door. Pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't sleep with the other girls. And leaves.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JACK'S ROOM- NIGHT
dialogues.text: JACK is asleep. He is not alone. In the bed beside him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pale as death. Eyes rolled back in her sockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK wakes up suddenly, gasping. The bed is empty, the sheets twisted and damp.

dialogues.speaker: SUNRISE...
dialogues.text: ...over one of the most desolate and beautiful landscapes all Italy.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JACK'S ROOM- DAWN
dialogues.text: In the gun-metal light of dawn, fiddly work: -cartridges taken apart -tiny holes drilled in the nose to a depth of precisely 3 -the hole half-filled with mercury -and plugged with a drop of liquid lead. JACK is converting jacketed ammunition into EXPLOSIVE BULLETS.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHURCH- DAY
dialogues.text: Outside, the sun is merciless. Inside, JACK has taken ref in the cool of the church. He is alone. He is not praying Just staring impassively at the gaudy crucifixion: at the thorns and the nails and the running blood. Footsteps. JACK checks for reflections in his watch. It's FATHER BENEDETTO: dressed for Mass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He mops the sweat from his brow with the hem of his Souta takes JACK by the arm and leads him to one side, away fro the light of the candles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man was here asking questions about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He came to the church this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To know where you live. He said he was a friend from Switzerland. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Switzerland? JACK thinks. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you told him? The priest looks at with complete disdain: FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I do not tell him. How do I know him? He is maybe the police. Certainly he is no friend. A friend would know your pensione. Besides... FATHER BENEDETTO leans close and whispers: FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friends do not carry guns. FATHER BENEDETTO glances shrewdly at JACK, his eyes searc into him. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you live in Italy, and you are a man of the cloth, you meet many people. Besides, I lived once in Naples. If you live in Naples you know the difference between a fat wallet and a... custodia per armi di spalla. How you say in English? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoulder holster. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si. JACK glances up and down the aisle. OLD LADIES are dribbling into church in twos and threes. The BELL for mass starts ringing. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a true friend, father. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a priest. JACK turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Signor Clarke? Again the priest leans close, holding JACK by the elbow i gesture of austere confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I make a mistake. He did not say he was from La Svizzera: Switzerland. He said- forgive me the names in Italian are so similar- La Svezia: Sweden.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHURCH, ROOF- DAY
dialogues.text: THREE BELLS are ringing in the tower. Beneath them, a row mediaeval GARGOYLES (dragons, griffins, dogs and devils) down over the little town, their faces frightening or frightened. JACK is among the gargoyles, leaning over parapet, his ey made huge by a pair of tiny binoculars, surveying the tow below, checking each square of the grid for a glimpse of YOUNG MAN. Nothing. Then he notices: Parked in the shadow of a spreading chestnut tree not far from the main square. An AUDI... ...with the YOUNG MAN we spotted in Castelveccio market sitting at the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, STREET- NIGHT
dialogues.text: The YOUNG MAN comes out of a shop. This is the first time we've seen him up close. In his ea thirties, he's wearing a dark brown leather jacket and expensive jeans. His blonde hair is cropped short, and there's the hint of a botched prison-cell tattoo visible beneath the collar of his shirt. The YOUNG MAN opens a small silver tin and a single deft movement removes a portion of SNUS (Swedish chewing tobac and inserts the it between his top lip and gum. It is a strangely sinister act. Then he blends in with the tourists, milling down the Cor and round the square heading towards...

dialogues.speaker: INT. BAR- NIGHT
dialogues.text: JACK is sitting in the window, making himself as visible possible to the world outside. He downs a Grappa: then gets up to pay for it. His moveme are slow and leisurely. The BARMAN hands him his change. And a small white ENVELO JACK is not expecting this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in ITALIAN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone left this for "L'Americano". This afternoon. JACK looks at the ENVELOPE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grazie. He turns casually away from the BARMAN's prying eyes and opens the envelope with extreme caution. Inside is a folded CUTTING. It's from the Swedish Daily newspaper Г–STERSUNDS-POSTEN. JACK unfolds the cutting. We catch a glimpse of: -Ingrid's dacha. -A police line. -Three dead bodies in the snow: the two hitmen and the gi Heart racing, JACK slips the cutting in his pocket. Grabs three SUGAR CUBES from a silver bowl on the bar. And leaves.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, TOWN SQUARE- NIGHT
dialogues.text: The YOUNG MAN is watching a PUPPET SHOW in the middle of square. The PUPPETEER is using glove puppets and the Punc and Judy style performance involves Punch fucking Judy wi grotesquely carved, outsize sex organ. There is a large c gathered. JACK leaves the bar, turning left and walking purposefull down the street. The YOUNG MAN follows.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, CORSO FREDERICO- NIGHT
dialogues.text: It's a hot summer night and there are more tourists than usual. The YOUNG MAN uses them as cover. JACK turns down a dark, deserted alleyway. The YOUNG MAN hesitates. His right hand moves casually to his jacket pocket. And he follows.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ALLEYWAY- NIGHT
dialogues.text: We're with the YOUNG MAN as he stalks his prey through th mediaeval maze of streets... We end up in the narrow alleyway that JACK photographed o his first day in town. Up ahead, disappearing round a distant bend, we catch a glimpse of JACK, his heels CLACKING on the cobbles. The YOUNG MAN follows swiftly, his trainers silent. He ge to a crossroads where FOUR NARROW ALLEYWAYS- all identica converge. The YOUNG MAN is unsure which alleyway to take. The streets are empty. He listens. From an upstairs window he can hear the soundtrack of a l night film on television. It's a romantic film, the violi muffled and sad with longing. From another alleyway comes the sound of SAVAGE BARKING. YOUNG MAN looks around for the source of the barking, but streets are empty. Suddenly, the barking stops. The YOUNG MAN looks confused. From his right hand jacket pocket we hear the unmistakabl CLICK of a cocking mechanism.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COURTYARD- NIGHT
dialogues.text: We're recognise the secret courtyard: the one reached by means of the hidden archway. With one hand, JACK feeds another SUGAR CUBE to the MONGR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the other hand, he holds his WALTHER behind his back ...and cocks it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ALLEYWAY- NIGHT
dialogues.text: The YOUNG MAN is waiting at the far end of the alleyway, hugging the wall, scanning the CROSSROADS ahead, unsure w of the four possible alleyways holds his prey. JACK emerges from the HIDDEN ARCHWAY and walks quickly up behind him. JACK has removed his shoes and his bare feet are silent. He has thirty metres to cover. The gun hangs heavy in his right hand. It's fitted with a TAC 65 SOUND SUPPRESSOR. H raises his right hand. Twenty metres. The gun is pointing at the YOUNG MAN. Fifteen metres. His finger takes up the slack of the trigger. Ten meters. Then: A DUCATI turns into the alleyway behind JACK, its headlig on full beam. JACK drops his right hand and thrusts his silenced WALTHE deep into his jacket pocket. The YOUNG MAN looks his way. JACK is outlined by the moped's beam of light. The two men are face to face, within spitting distance. The DUCATI hurtles towards the YOUNG MAN. The MAN ON THE DUCATI is wearing a tinted BLACK CRASH HEL The YOUNG MAN's eyes widen with fear.

dialogues.speaker: BANG
dialogues.text: The DUCATI misfires. Mistaking the sound for gunfire, the YOUNG MAN drops, rol and fires back. We hear the sound of a single suppressed shot: CHOOP!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BULLET grazes the FRONT SUSPENSION of the DUCATI and lodges in the REAR COWLING. The MAN ON THE DUCATI swerves and crashes, hitting a ston staircase. JACK looks around. The YOUNG MAN has disappeared. The MAN ON THE DUCATI is out cold. The front wheel of his DUCATI turns slowly, squeaking.

dialogues.speaker: CHOOP
dialogues.text: A bullet hits the road not far from JACK.

dialogues.speaker: CHOOP
dialogues.text: Another bullet hits the wall behind him. Swiftly, JACK grabs hold of the battered 1970s DUCATI...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, MEDIAVEVAL MAZE- NIGHT
dialogues.text: JACK rides the classic DUCATI, turning left and right wit hesitation, through archways, down steps, dropping level level, cursing in time with his jagged breathing until...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, OUTSKIRTS OF TOWN- NIGHT
dialogues.text: JACK emerges from the bottom of the town and races away o the winding road. Silence. All we can hear are the crickets. Then the sound of a car. An AUDI tears past us, following JACK out of town.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ALPINE ROAD- NIGHT
dialogues.text: JACK is heading for the mountains. He takes the first cor at 70 MPH. The AUDI gleams black in the moonlight. Gaining on him.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: JACK takes the next bend at top speed, his classic 1970 1000cc engine howling. The AUDI slows, then powers through the bend, acceleratin

dialogues.speaker: INT. AUDI- NIGHT
dialogues.text: The YOUNG MAN puts his foot down. The SPEEDOMETER climbs.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ALPINE ROAD- NIGHT
dialogues.text: The AUDI comes up swiftly behind Jack's DUCATI and tries ram him. JACK dodges the AUDI, swerving from one side of the road another.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VIADUCT- NIGHT
dialogues.text: A soaring concrete bridge spans a plunging alpine valley. The AUDI overtakes the DUCATI, then swerves left, trying crush JACK against the concrete barrier that masks a thre hundred and fifty foot fall. JACK breaks hard and the AUDI misses him, smashing into t concrete barrier amidst a shower of sparks and screeching metal. The AUDI follows the DUCATI into...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ALPINE TUNNEL- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Long, dark, neon-lit... and blind curved. The AUDI comes up fast behind the DUCATI. Jack swerves the DUCATI onto the other side of the road. The AUDI swerves left and tries to crush JACK into the le hand wall of the tunnel. Suddenly, a CAR comes round the bend. What happens next happens fast: JACK swerves left and skids into a SERVICE LAY-BY, narrow avoiding the CAR. The lay-by is small and JACK has to slide the DUCATI on i side as he crashes it into the box-like space. The lay-by is too small for the AUDI. The AUDI and oncoming CAR collide. The AUDI's crumple zones buckle as both vehicles' bonnets concertina like a road safety test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The AUDI has air bags. The oncoming CAR does not. On impact, its DRIVER goes through the windscreen of his car and onwards, through the windscreen of the AUDI. The wreckage is awesome. Deep within the mangled metal of the two cars... ...the YOUNG MAN groans and twitches. JACK appears at the crumpled window of the AUDI. He reaches through the broken window, grabs the YOUNG MAN the head... ...and breaks his neck.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODS- DAWN
dialogues.text: JACK washes away the worst of the dirt and the blood in a MOUNTAIN STREAM.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROAD- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK on the DUCATI. Turns off at a sign for L'AQUILA.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. L'AQUILA- MORNING
dialogues.text: L'AQUILA is the nearest and largest town in the region. I also the location of the Via Lampedusa brothel. JACK comes out of a pharmacy and quite literally bumps in CLARA. He winces with pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buon giorno!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buon giorno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing really. Just a broken rib. Un costollo rotta?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stronzo! Let me help you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came off my bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you have to go to the hospital!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no. I have pain killers. I just need a strong cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a place which make the strongest coffee in L'Aquila.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her limpid brown eyes twinkle.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLARA'S APARTMENT- DAY
dialogues.text: A small, simply furnished bedroom with a bed, a desk and chair. As he sips a large cup of strong black coffee, CLARA clea vicious welt on his right shoulder blade. As the dirt and blood come away she reveals an exquisite tattoo... ...of a BUTTERFLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ve bene. Tutto posto. Signor Farfalla. [Good. Everything's OK. Mr. Butterfly.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes open wide and he turns to her quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why d'you call me that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a tattoo. On your back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. He relaxes. But not completely.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTELVECCHIO- DAY
dialogues.text: The situation at the beginning of the movie is perfectly reversed. From the relative safety of CASTELVECCHIO, JACK watches CASTEL DEL MONTE through binoculars: -The Phone Box. -The Bar. -The pensione D'Abruzzo. No sign of the police. No sign of any Shadow Dwellers.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, TOWN SQUARE- SUNSET
dialogues.text: JACK is in his usual phone box. His manner is quietly purposeful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did he know I was here, Larry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I hired him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you out of your fucking mind, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After everything I've done for you? The car, the cell phone (which you threw away), the safehouse, the fake passport? Someone has to pay for this shit, Jack! I have to pay for this shit. It comes out of my commission. You're my lousy profit margin. Why the fuck would I take a contract out on my own profit margin? You're not thinking straight. I was the one who told you to leave town! I told you to come to Rome! God damn it you've got a job to do! Why the Hell would I...

dialogues.speaker: WHAM
dialogues.text: Something smacks into the phone box at high speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK drops to his knees and reaches for his WALTHER. Outside the phone box three TEENAGERS are kicking a FOOTB around.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JACK'S ROOM- NIGHT
dialogues.text: TINS of fruit drops: three kinds: black cherry, pineapple lemon. Each tin is emptied of its fruit drops. Twenty rounds of ammunition- each round packed in silica- exactly into each tin. Lead rounds in the black cherry, jacketed in the pineappl and explosive in the lemon. JACK re-seals each tin with sellotape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The colonnades of this popular pedestrain street are crow with window shoppers, tourists taking coffee, old men discussing politics and office girls walking hand in hand chattering like songbirds. JACK is in dark glasses. He's sitting in a coffee shop un the colonnade sucking a fruit drop and reading a copy of Messagiero. C.U. we see he's studying a small column concerning the murder of two prostitutes in the nearby city of Chieti. JACK spots CLARA walking along the corso. She's with a gi he has not seen before. ANNA. ANNA is small town girl wit keen sense of fashion. She and CLARA are hand in hand. CLARA sees JACK and speaks to her friend. They cross through the throng of boulevardiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend Anna. This is my friend Signor Farfalla. CLARA's eyes twinkle mischievously. The girls cease to hold hands and ANNA offers hers to JAC JACK half rises like the perfect gentlemen, folding his newspaper and accepting ANNA's greeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am very well thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. This is to be an impromptu English lesson. JACK acquiesces gracefully. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you take a coffee with me? CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be very good. He indicates two empty chairs. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prego. CLARA moves her chair to sit closer to JACK. Under the ta her knee presses against his. ANNA also moves her chair nearer to JACK: but her motive to move it out of the sun. She is not flirting. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is learning English. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been to England? ANNA seems momentarily confused. ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you are... She looks at CLARA. ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lui Americano? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. JACK glances at CLARA. How much has she told her friend? ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. I have not been to England only to France. But I would love to go to America. The WAITER comes over. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Due cappuccini e un cafe corretto. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is like all Italians. She thinks America is like in the movies. Little Italy, "West Side Story", "Chicago". (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARA (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell her in these times America is like here, there, anywhere. The streets are not... pave-ed with gold. She beams happily at JACK. He smiles back at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If not with gold, than at least not with enough medieval cobbles to loosen every-self tapping screw in a Fiat. JACK beams. Neither girl understands. But everyone smiles happily. The WAITER brings the coffee and CLARA insists on paying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you come from, Anna? ANNA frowns. JACK plays teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dove abita?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, yes! I live in Via dell' Argilla. Nearby to Clara. JACK briefly wonders what else he could teach her. He sca both girls and decides CLARA is the prettier. CLARA seems sense this. She smiles to herself. JACK is touched.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CORSO FREDERICO II, L'AQUILA- DAY
dialogues.text: We cut wide and watch JACK talk inconsequentialities with girls. They stand to go. JACK rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps we will have a drink together soon? I am free... Her words sound rehearsed. She considers a crowded timeta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...on Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. I'll see you then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Eduardo... Where would you like to meet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again: rehearsed. JACK is not expecting this. CLARA looks him mischievously. ANNA is listening. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about our usual place? CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our usual place? She feigns complete perplexity. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot. Where is our usual place? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've forgotten? CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remind me. The twinkle in her eye. She's testing him. JACK is the perfect gentleman. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should try something different. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where would you like to try, Eduardo? A beat. JACK spots a restaurant on the opposite side of t road. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locanda Grapelli? There is no warmth in his suggestion. But CLARA doesn't c CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locanda Grapelli! Si! She looks genuinely delighted. ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the best food in the area. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locanda Grapelli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locanda Grapelli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you then, Eduardo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you then, Clara. It was a delight to meet you Anna. Arrivederci.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrivederci, Signor Farfalla. There is an unmistakable twinkle in ANNA's eye. How much knows is uncertain. She kisses him swiftly and softly on cheek. CLARA does the same on the lips. Behind the mischief in h eyes is something doubtful. Has she gone too far?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOWNTOWN L'AQUILA- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK visits three stores: -In a PHOTOGRAPHIC SHOP he buys half a dozen FILM PROTECT BAGS. -In a HABERDASHERS he purchases several packets of HOOKS EYES like the kind you find on brassieres. -In a OFFICE SUPPLY SHOP he buys some custom made headed notepaper, invoice books, notepads, envelopes, metal pens calculator and a mobile phone.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JACK'S ROOM- NIGHT
dialogues.text: JACK opens a black combination lock SAMSONITE BRIEFCASE a lines the bottom and sides with the lead-lined film protection bags, cut to fit. Into the base of the briefcase he glues pre-shaped pieces firm grey plastic foam. These form the pockets into which slots the constituent parts of the SOCIMI SUBMACHINE GUN. They fit perfectly. Over this JACK uses the HOOKS and EYES to clip a false bottom: a tough card cover onto which are pasted the cust made headed notepaper, invoice books, notepads and envelo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the briefcase's central divider he adds the metal pens calculator and a mobile phone. He sets the combination to 821. Then shuts and locks the BRIEFCASE. This done he sits on the bed and stares at the case. With work complete, he is struck by a terrible sense of emptin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small park not far from Castel Del Monte's town square. It is just after dawn. The pine trees and the poplars are silent. The sun is not yet up but the day is light. Sparr hop about, searching for crumbs. JACK, ravaged by lack of sleep, wonders about like the de of a lost darkness, looking for his hole down to the underworld.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buon giorno! He's twenty meters away, his hand raised in half-welcome, half-benediction. They greet one another and FATHER BENEDETTO falls into sl step with JACK. The priest walks with his hands behind hi back. JACK with his hands in his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I walk here to meditate. Once a week, Wednesday, the farthest one can travel in the week from the Sabbath. The trees are like the Stations of the Cross: by certain trees I thank God for certain favours he has granted me, or certain gifts he has made to me and all men. For example, here by this pine, I thank him for the many friendships I have and ask him to look after those of my friends who are troubled. They reach a Cypress tree and FATHER BENEDETTO bows his h in prayer. After a while he says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some walk here in the cool of evening. Others come at night. There is a slight sadness in his voice as he says to hims

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder how many bastards have been made here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives a small sideways glance at JACK. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you'll stay and settle here yourself? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think I'm leaving? FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me as much when we first met. Besides, those who seek for peace seldom find it. They're always moving on, looking elsewhere. [A BEAT] And they are usually sinners. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All men are sinners. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some are greater sinners than others. And those who seek peace have much sinning in their history. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't seek peace. I never have. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until now. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps. Perhaps I'll stay. The valley. The villages. The mountains. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me. This is the priest in me speaking. And the friend. But you have done much sinning, Signor Clarke. You still do. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see a whore. She's young enough to be my daughter. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not refer to the sins of carnality. But to the deadly sins... JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't all sins equal? FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are not discussing theology, my friend, but you. You like this town, this valley. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FATHER BENEDETTO (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should like to remain here and find your peace at last. Yet you cannot. There is something you cannot ignore. Some force. Some enemy. JACK is silent. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to speak but you dare not. You know no one sufficiently well to share your history with them. You know I am trustworthy yet still you are cautious. FATHER BENEDETTO stops, compelling JACK to stop too- and him. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What job do you do, Signor? Are you on the run, as they say? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who says? FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an expression, no? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's on the run from something. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some men watch some of the shadows. You watch them all. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done nothing I didn't have good cause to do. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you wish to tell me? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what reason? FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For your own sake. Perhaps I can pray for you? A change of pace. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I make things. Artifacts. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Counterfeit money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you say that? FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You work in metal. You are given some steel by Fabio, the car doctor. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know a lot about me. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know only what you do in the town. People talk to me. I am their priest and they trust me. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I should too? FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. They stare at one another. JACK wants to confess. He does not know why. But he doesn't. He does something we're not expecting: JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fabio. The `car doctor'. Was he conceived here father? FATHER BENEDETTO is motionless. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you ask me that? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks like you. Even more than he does in the photos you keep of each other. Where was he conceived, father? Under one of these trees? At night? Like all the other bastards? There is a very, very long pause. FATHER BENEDETTO stares at JACK with extraordinary intensity. FATHER BENEDETTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not remember, Signor. It was twenty-five years ago. FATHER BENEDETTO walks. JACK follows. A gust of wind make dust swirl from the gravel path. The two men do not speak again until they reach the next set of Cyprus trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the end it is I who confesses to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Expecting me to reciprocate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps. For your own good. You cannot doubt the existence of Hell. You live in it. It is a place without love. As for me, I go about my daily duties because the town requires it of me. Some know what you know. Perhaps I have no right to wear these robes. But I do have a heart full of a father's love. Something close to His heart! And for that I am both grateful and happy. On JACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you have, my friend? Another gust of wind. The priest looks up into JACK's fac The assassin's eyes are red and stinging. Perhaps its fro the dust.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JACK'S ROOM- EVENING
dialogues.text: JACK dresses very carefully for dinner. It is clear he wishes to make a favourable impression upo CLARA.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LOCANDA GRAPELLI- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Stone steps lead up from the street to large paved verand that overlooks the town. Overhead a canopy of vine and jasmine. Above that a sky full of stars. Of the thirty or so candle-lit tables that dot the verand more than half are occupied by romantic couples. JACK scans the tables and checks his watch. It's shortly after seven pm and there's no sign of CLARA. He waits. Then turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ciao.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him once on the lips. She's hot and flustered. She's been rushing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did not think you would come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't sure you meant me to. CLARA looks doubtful. It's the same look she gave him at cafe. She is breaking the golden rule of prostitution. Getting involved. Her heart is pulling one way and her he another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certo. A WAITER approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Per due? Judging by his disapproving tone, the WAITER seems to kno what CLARA does for a living. CLARA senses this immediate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LOCANDA GRAPPELLI- NIGHT
dialogues.text: CLARA and JACK sit at a table overlooking the town. The WAITER lights their candle and deposits two menus peremptorily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Una botiglia di acqua minerale non gasata et... una Parasini, per favore. Completely ignoring her, the WAITER addresses JACK with a wink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Menu in Inglese? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, grazie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tedesco? Olandese?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the WAITER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He speaks Italian. So do I. Listen:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She repeats her order, articulating each word emphaticall like a teacher to a slow school child: CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Una botiglia di acqua minerale et una Parasini, per favore. She isn't upset. It's just her way of letting both men kn that she's in charge. The WAITER turns to her, deferring to her strength of character. WAITER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gasata? CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Non gasata. He nods with some genuine deference and leaves. CLARA sighs. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mostly to herself) Cittadina. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small towns. JACK smiles. CLARA smiles back. They have this contempt i common. The WAITER reappears and pours a thumbful of wine. It is red in colour and frizzante. At CLARA's insistence, JACK tastes it. It is dry and has a tar-like aftertaste. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parasini. From Calabria. It is good, you will agree? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is. Very good. He looks at her and- for a brief moment- he undergoes wha a unique experience for him: a positive longing to repeat this brief moment many times in the future. CLARA catches the glow of his warmth and blossoms. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something, Eduardo? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. A beat. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt any of the couples here are. With the exception of the Germans at table seven. She's wearing a wedding ring and they haven't spoken a word to each other for eight and half minutes. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was sure this was your secret. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think I have a secret? I'm an ordinary man. I cough. I fart. I earn a living. JACK observes a GYPSY selling roses. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not think you are an ordinary man. I think you are a good man. But you have a secret. The GYPSY approaches, offering CLARA a ROSE. She refuses firmly. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks we are a couple. JACK signals to the GYPSY and buys CLARA a ROSE. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why spoil the illusion? She looks at him and smiles. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in ITALIAN) As long as we know it is an illusion. Her smile is only a little bit sad. Still, JACK doesn't know what to say. They are saved by the appearance of the WAITER. WAITER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buona sera. Desidera? CLARA orders, full of Italian charm, putting JACK at his ease. He watches her contentedly: the way she talks and moves.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CORSO FREDERICO- NIGHT
dialogues.text: JACK   and CLARA are walking. He has a cigarette in his m They   look like film stars. CLARA slips her arm through They   say nothing. The pedestrian shopping street is thr with   other couples.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COFFEE BAR- NIGHT
dialogues.text: The coffee bar has an outside section. CLARA and L'AMERIC are seated in a throng of happy youngsters Clara's age. J is the oldest person there. The WAITRESS brings two glasses of PROSECCO. She puts a s silver bowl of raspberry ice cream down in front of JACK. front of CLARA she puts down an extravagant ice cream sun CLARA grins at her sundae like a little girl. She's a bit drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woooow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She eats, savoring the ice cream. JACK watches, savoring pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitchin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) Bitchin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's- come se dice- `slang', no? Eco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She scoops a spoonful dripping with nuts and chocolate sa and holds it out to JACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Eduardo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hesitates. He eats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is good, you will agree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his mouth full) I will agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sensing his teasing) My English is nice! JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's bitchin'. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defending herself) You know how to swear in Italian? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Bastardo. Imbecile. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Imbecile?" Eduardo! Try: Mangia merde e morte: tuo cazzo un brufolo. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat shit and die, pimple dick? CLARA hiccups. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perdone! JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I've led a sheltered life. Of sorts. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shell-tered? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too much work. CLARA's CELL PHONE starts to ring. It's on silent, but th screen is flashing, just visible where it sticks out of h handbag. CLARA looks down at the phone. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too much work. She turns the phone to silent. And looks up at JACK. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't apologise, Eduardo. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what? CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For this I do. My job. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never apologise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He means it. A beat. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except this job is full of testa di cazzo. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine too. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lei? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you are too young to... pensione? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Retire. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liar. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you be flattering me if I wasn't a client? He's put CLARA on the spot. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I a client? CLARA takes a deep breath. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This say yes. She points at her head. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This... She points at her heart. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This cannot be for sale. But I am not want to... come se dice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it away. She looks at him. JACK studies her, searching for his own feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stronzo! I buy you a present! She fishes about in her handbag... ...and produces a SILVER BOX. JACK unwraps the shiny paper. Inside is a plastic case li the sort you put engagement rings in. Inside the case is BADGE, hand-painted, depicting the symbol of the region: eagle of L'Aquila. JACK sticks the BADGE in his lapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grazie. An embarrassed beat. CLARA kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grazie, Clara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prego. Eduardo. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My apartment is not far from here.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLARA'S APARTMENT- MORNING
dialogues.text: JACK opens his eyes. Sits up. He's shocked to have slept so deeply. CLARA must be in the shower. He looks around at the little room casually, like a curio lover. Opens the top drawer of the bedside cabinet. Finds a VIBRATOR. Opens the bottom drawer. Finds a RED PURSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the RED PURSE... Finds a BERETTA DOUBLE-ACTION MODEL 21A BOBCAT. Just at that moment CLARA comes out of the bathroom. JACK shuts the drawer and pretends to be asleep.

dialogues.speaker: EXT.PAY PHONE- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK has driven to the remotest phone box he can find: no far from the entrance to one of the region's four nationa parks: beside a lake, below a mountain range and approach by a long, straight, empty road. No one could possibly creep up on him here. Nevertheless, he talks, JACK makes his habitual and continuous 360 scan the area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're moving the drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know yet. I'll call you ten am on the day with a venue. Give you enough time to make the noon delivery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't deliver, Larry. I never deliver. It's too dangerous. She comes to me. I know the town. That's what we agreed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told `em. I told `em if there was even the slightest chance security had been breached, you'd have dealt with it immediately. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breach? What breach? For the first time in the movie we cut to LARRY at home:

dialogues.speaker: INT. LARRY'S APARTMENT, ROME- DAY
dialogues.text: LARRY is sitting in a high back leather office chair befo large, imperial mahogany desk. In front of him are two ba of screens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first bank displays 3 CCTV views: (1) the entrance to apartment block (2) a staircase and (3) the entrance to h apartment itself. Another bank of screens shows 3 NEWS CHANNELS: (1) CNN, ( BBC WORLD and (3) AL JAZEERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our pretty young Belgian client and her associates think someone on your long list of enemies might have put a tail on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course not, Jack. But if, for the sake of argument, it was possible- I'm thinking it could be Galazzo. Or Simenov. Or Italian undercover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crooked kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come I'm still here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Belgians think they're planning to wait for the drop and exterminate you and Mathilde in one swoop. With the help of his DESKTOP computer LARRY is comparing scrolling share prices on CNN with the fluctuating value the US DOLLAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell's this information coming from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fucked if I know, Jack. If you want my opinion, they're just being jittery. I told `em you were the most security conscious professional I know. I told `em no one gets close to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told `em if we couldn't trust you to keep a tight lid on operations the who could we trust?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can. They can trust me and so can you. JACK is tense. Every word is carefully enunciated:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never jeopardised an operation in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to tell me that, Jack. For Christ's sake, you closed your own girlfriend's account... ECU on JACK.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LARRY'S APARTMENT, ROME- DAY
dialogues.text: The words are out before he can stop them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack? [A BEAT] Jack? I'm sorry. He rubs his eyes, wearied by his own insensitivity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was, um.... I'm just saying you can be relied on. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack? CLICK.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PAY PHONE- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK has hung up. He is lost in fearful thought, jaw muscles grinding.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHURCH, ROOF- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Amongst the GARGOYLES... ...JACK, looking through his miniature binoculars. His POV:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of CLARA seated in a cafe talking to a slick, tough YOUNG ITALIAN MAN in a suit. He is showing her photographs. Of what- we cannot see. CL looks very, very serious. The YOUNG ITALIAN MAN leaves. JACK watches him get into a smart black ALFA ROMEO containing two other ITALIAN MEN. plates. When he looks back at the cafe, CLARA has gone.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PENSIONE ABRUZZO, JACK'S ROOM- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK opens his PICNIC HAMPER and in it he puts: -a polystyrene cool box packed with ice and containing a chilled bottle of Aspirinio -a loaf of course bread -two clods of mozarella -150 gms of proscuitto -and his WALTHER PPK/S.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE- DAY
dialogues.text: CLARA is waiting on the Via Strinella near the entrance t the Parco della Resistanza, sheltering in the shade of a tree. She is holding the RED PURSE. At her feet is blue plastic rounded out by a watermelon. JACK pulls his CAR into the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ciao, Eduardo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the passenger door, leans in and kisses JACK lo and full on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put them in the back. We've got a way to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts the plastic bag in the trunk. Inside the trunk is the PICNIC HAMPER.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR- DAY
dialogues.text: CLARA climbs in and fastens her seat-belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts the RED PURSE between her legs. JACK glances at RED PURSE. And drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swimming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far do we go? To Fanale?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An hour. And we're not going to the sea, we're going to the lakes. In the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a... come se dice... you have in the back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A picnic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pick-nick! We are going for a pick-nick. Just the two of us. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have practise my English, Eduardo. I love to have pick-nick. It is a beautiful day, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ALPINE ROAD- DAY
dialogues.text: The CAR negotiates a familiar hairpin bend.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR- DAY
dialogues.text: CLARA is station hopping. She finds some LOU REED. She loves LOUD REED. JACK is concentrating on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it more far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten kilometres. Another twenty minutes. She pauses to work out the mathematics. She's smart. And puzzled. But she's not frightened. Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve kilometres? In twenty minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going off the beaten track. She looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lontano. Fuori mano. CLARA laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will speak Italian. One day, I will teach you.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ALPINE TRACK- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK turns off the main road and onto an alpine track. This is the same route he took with the Belgian woman. The CAR bumps and tilts on the rough terrain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARA is startled by such an insignificant track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going? Now she's anxious. This is not what she expected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shall see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it is good we should stay close to the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no need to worry. I've been here before several times. Taking photographs. He swings the wheel suddenly to avoid a large boulder and Citroen pitches as if struck by a wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARA clings to the door with her right hand, her left ha dug deep into the fabric of the seat to steady herself. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not afraid of coming into the wild with me, are you? CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! She laughs tensely. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I am not. Not with you. But this... She snaps her fingers. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...sentiero! She waves her hand in the air. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have a jeep. A Toyota. It is not good for a... berlina. It's as if the increased danger of the track diminishes h English. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a Citroen! He strikes the steering wheel hard with the palm of his h JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was made by the French for taking potatoes to market. Besides, I always come here in this car. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. I don't want to walk back to town any more than you do. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you are crazy. This will go to nowhere. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assure you it does. She pouts her reply. The TRACK disappears into a WOOD and runs out altogether, giving way to grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now there is no road! JACK stops the car and turns the engines off. Sudden silence. CLARA lets go of the seat. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this where we go? They are surrounded by trees. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not quite. We go another hundred metres, through the wood. But from here we just roll forward. No motor. No sound. And you'll see a wonder. She grips the seat again. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't need to hold on. I'll go slowly. Just relax and look. He eases his foot off the brake and the car begins to mov forward, the springs squeaking slightly. After 50 metres twists the steering wheel slightly and applies the brakes They roll gradually down to the outer edge of the woods a come to a stop beneath a familiarly squat but ample WALNU TREE. Beyond them is the LAKE, the MEADOWS and the RUINED HAMLE The hidden valley is a riot of colour, the blooms and blossoms more brilliant than we've ever seen them. By the edge of the lake stands a HERON, still as fence post. CLARA gets out of the car, dumbstruck. JACK gets out too. watches her... then swiftly checks the ruined hamlet thro his miniature binoculars. Deserted. By the time CLARA tur towards him, the binoculars are hidden. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one comes here? She speaks so quietly JACK can barely hear her. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just you. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARA turns away, unbuttons her blouse and drops it on th grass. She is wearing no bra. On her back dapple the shad and patches of sun eking through the branches of the waln She kicks off her shoes, which curve through the air... a unzips her skirt. It falls to the grass. She bends and st daintily from her knickers. Then turns to face JACK. JACK cannot take his eyes off her. Dizzy, he steps forwar without meaning to. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? She is coquettish- and tosses her auburn hair to one side CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am going to swim in the lake. Are you coming? She doesn't wait for his reply, but turns and runs throug the grass towards the water. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are vipers! Vipera! Marasso! CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe! But I am lucky! The HERON flies off, rising from the reeds with an ungain flapping. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) He is an Italian bird! We disturb his siesta! Quickly, JACK glances inside the CITROEN. The RED PURSE is nowhere to be seen. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Signor Farfalla! JACK undresses. As he removes his clothes, he stalls for time, using the cover of undressing to search for the RED PURSE. We can see it wedged under the passenger seat. Due to the design of the car, JACK cannot. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come! JACK turns to face the lake. He is naked. Yet with the caution of years he does not remove his shoes until he reaches the water's edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARA is standing in the middle. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand by me. He obeys her order. He walks out to her and she takes his hand under the water, holding it out in front of them. JACK spots it resting on the smooth stone of the lake-bed Brassy and gleaming. A SPENT SHELL. He covers it with his foot. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep still. Watch. As the ripples of his arrival peter out in the reeds, TIN FISH appear in a shoal to gather about their hands. They hover like slivers of glass just under the surface then m in to nibble at the skin on their fingers. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we stay here for a year, they'll devour us. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is said that if these fishes bite at two hands holding, then love is good for the people. He looks at her and for a moment he forgets the awful pla his head. She kisses him, pressing herself against him, her skin an body as pure and warm as the water. He tries helplessly to pull away. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should... CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you make love in the water? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't. She places her arms around his neck and raises her feet f the smooth stones, wrapping her legs around his waist. Sh tries to push herself onto him but he resists. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong? He doesn't know what to say. She looks at him: confused, searching. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks towards the bank. She follows. The tiny fish dar around them for a few moments then flee for the reeds, travelling with the waves made by their departure.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LAKESIDE- DAY
dialogues.text: CLARA is lying naked on a blanket. Beside her is the RED PURSE. Through sleepy, half-closed eyes she is watching L'AMERIC From her POV, JACK is kneeling behind the open PICNIC HAM unpacking the food and wine. The LID of the basket obscur his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eduardo. JACK looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this your real name? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Clara yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si. Yes. She looks at him. Waiting for his reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward is my real name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed-ward. She doesn't believe him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are sure you are not married, Eduardo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite sure. About this he's telling the truth. CLARA reaches for the RED PURSE. From behind the picnic hamper lid we hear the CLICK of a cocking mechanism. CLARA hesitates for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK watches her intently. She reaches into her purse. JACK is expressionless. When CLARA withdraws her right hand she is holding a tube SUNTAN LOTION. A beat. JACK watches as she commences smoothing it into her skin, rubbing it around her breasts, pushing them aside, pressi them upwards. Then she caresses the lotion into her belly down her thighs, bending at the waist as she works it int her shins. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you put this on my back? She proffers him the SUNTAN LOTION. JACK stares at her baking body, transfixed by its terribl and perfect beauty. Hidden behind the LID of the picnic hamper... ...his trembling right hand grips tightly to his WALTHER. A long pause. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eduardo? He's frozen. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amore? Time seems to stop. ECU on JACK. Suddenly, CLARA sits up. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eduardo, what's wrong? JACK swallows. When he speaks his mouth his dry. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. When he moves towards her, he is holding nothing in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the tube of SUNTAN lotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Father Benedetto... And begins to run it into CLARA's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promised myself that I would write to you- as your friend- to say goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: SLAM
dialogues.text: JACK shuts the boot of the car. He scans the lakeside. No sign of the picnic. No sign of CLARA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything I've ever done... Then he spots something. On the ground, not far from the car. He walks over and picks it up. It's one of CLARA's shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done for a reason. JACK is staring at the SHOE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never thought the day would come when I'd run out of reasons. Reasons to worry. Reasons to run. Reasons to pull the trigger. JACK turns and walks over to the car. CLARA is in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe that day's come. JACK gets into the Citroen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or maybe I've just found a reason to change. And hands CLARA her shoe. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grazie, Eduardo. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't understand. What's the point of a gun if it's not loaded? CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the girls borrow it to me after the second hooker in Chieti is murdered. With some of the clients it make me feel safe. I don't tell the police, of course, but... Madonna, Eduardo. How they do to these two women! A police agente from Rome show me photographs. They show photographs to everyone in Via Lampedusa. CLARA shivers with disgust. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Non capito... how one person hurt another in this way. JACK looks lost, like a man drained of all resolution. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does the gun make you feel safer with me? CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not a client. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why's it in your purse? CLARA looks unhappy. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to work tonight, amore. Silence. JACK looks away. JACK (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe this is suicide. Cops often put the graft on working girls. Perhaps the girl I told you about, Clara, has sold me out. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK (V.O.) (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she's a cop herself, or maybe she's a hired gun. Then again, maybe Clara is who she says she is and my Belgian clients will take the gun, shoot me themselves and keep the money. Always a risk in my profession. Or perhaps my trusted colleague in Rome no longer trusts me. Perhaps even you, Father, with your connections in Naples... CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will you do? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'll go to work too. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And after that? Tomorrow and the next day. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stay here forever. As the words leave his lips he thinks how much he wishes could. JACK (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that I've given up on life, Father. Just the way that I was living it. If you can call it living. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want always to stay here. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time to go home. CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me come to your home. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't, Clara. One day... She's upset but decides not to press her demand. JACK (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I had one request, Father, it would be this. That it's not Clara who finally pulls the trigger. But whoever it is... CLARA kisses him and simply says: CLARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay forever here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...by this time tomorrow I'll be dead. Fade to black.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. CHURCH- DAY
dialogues.text: A POSTMAN hands the mail to FATHER BENEDETTO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ciao Fabio, come stai?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bene grazie, Padre. We follow FATHER BENEDETTO inside as he rifles through a bunch of church circulars. One LETTER catches his eye. He opens it and starts to read aloud:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Father Benedetto. I promised myself that I would write to you- as your friend- to say goodbye...

dialogues.speaker: INT. JACK'S ROOM- DAWN
dialogues.text: JACK stands by the door in a impeccably pressed suit, the black SAMSONITE BRIEFCASE in his hand. He surveys his room. All evidence of his existence has be meticulously tidied away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything I've ever done... JACK leaves. Only thing is left behind: The book of MEDIEVAL ITALIAN ART & ARCHITECTURE on th bedside table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done for a reason.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. AUTOSTRADA- DAY
dialogues.text: The sun is shining. The mountains young and sharp and beautiful. The CAR moves swiftly across the viaduct that spans a spectacular gorge and plunges into a long tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK watches the road. On the long straights he looks backwards and forwards.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SERVICE STATION- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK comes off the autostrada on a slip road and pulls in forecourt consisting of several rows of Agip and Q8 pumps convenience shop, a repair garage and a cafe. The car park is not large. JACK parks the Citroen facing EXIT. There is a single bar across it but this is raised. JACK double checks the magazine in his handgun is full an slips his WALTHER into his jacket pocket. Stepping out of the car he looks around the car park. It' only a quarter full and ominously quiet. Somewhere in the distance we can hear a sound: creak, creak, creak, creak. JACK takes the BRIEFCASE from the rear seat and walks awa He makes a show of locking the car but doesn't. As he approaches the CAFE he passes the GARAGE. We see th source of the creak, creak, creaking sound: a SIGN for en oil, on hinges, revolving slowly in the breeze.

dialogues.speaker: INT. AUTOSTRADA CAFE- DAY
dialogues.text: Empty. JACK sits at a table at the back of the cafe. From here h can see both entrances: the public entrance and the servi entrance and also the door to the bathrooms. Through the window, he has a good view of the garage forecourt and th slip road to and from the autostrada. JACK places the BRIEFCASE on a chair beside him and puts PAPER BAG on the table next to the sugar dispenser. He ch his watch. It is two minutes before noon. He orders an espresso. His nerve-heightened senses take in everything: the sound the cicadas, the buzz of the neon strip-lights and the cr creak, creak of the engine oil sign outside, endlessly revolving. JACK's eyes flick outside to the forecourt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the cafe door open. And in an instant, MATHILDE is at his table. She is dressed in a tight black skirt, a simple blue blou and a dark blue jacket. Her hair is neatly styled, her ma up immaculate and heavier than we've seen her wear before She looks exactly like the kind of woman who might carry Samsonite briefcase. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. I see you have brought it in from the car with you. She speaks quietly: her voice low and attractive. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All there, as agreed. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in the paper bag? The WAITRESS comes over with Jack's coffee. MATHILDE orde another for herself. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweets. For your journey. She opens the bag and takes out one of the TINS. She can immediately feel that it's heavier than it should JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guessed you'd have a sweet tooth. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is most thoughtful of you. The polite phrase sounds even more polite with her slight Belgian accent. The WAITRESS returns with the second espresso and MATHILD pays for them both. JACK watches as she stirs her coffee to cool it. She's nervous. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose I'll read about this in the Times or the International Herald Tribune. Or Il Maessagiero. For a moment she is pensive. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I expect so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drinks her coffee, holding her cup in mid-air and loo out the window. JACK follows her eye-line to check she's not signalling t accomplice. The FORECOURT is still empty. Creak, creak, creak, creak... MATHILDE looks at JACK. Her expression is impossible to r Perhaps it's tinged with sadness. She drinks the rest of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just going to the ladies. Wait here. She picks up the CASE. There is nothing JACK can do about this. She has taken hi off guard and grasped the initiative. All he can do is wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATHILDE enters a cubicle, opens the CASE, bypasses the stationary, lifts the false bottom and checks the SOCIMI parts are present and correct. Then she loads a magazine.

dialogues.speaker: INT. AUTOSTRADA CAFE- DAY
dialogues.text: MATHILDE returns from the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we go. Not a question, a command. JACK is obliged to stand up.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. AUTOSTRADA, CAR PARK- DAY
dialogues.text: MATHILDE walks towards a large FORD. She is carrying the BRIEFCASE. JACK has his right hand in his jacket pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't need your piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slang word belies her. For an instant she has forgott her Belgian accent. She sounds American. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never know. She stops beside the FORD. JACK still has his hands on the Walther. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: OK
dialogues.text: JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. You? MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's just fine. She definitely sounds American now. Her RIGHT HAND slips into her pocket. JACK twists his wrist upwards and thumbs the cocking leve MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Final payment. She hands JACK an ENVELOPE. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buy yourself a retirement clock. Her American accent shows that she's letting her guard do Maybe it's designed to make JACK do the same. It doesn't. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know I'm retiring? She leans forward and kisses him lightly and quickly and the lips. MATHILDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you taken your girl up to the meadow yet? JACK doesn't answer. His whole body is tense for the bull that he knows his coming. Perhaps there is a second perso the car. Just then... ...a COACH pulls into the car park. It stops with a hydraulic hiss and dozens of TEENAGE KIDS descend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATHILDE looks both irritated and relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers to JACK) Do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets into the driver's seat of the FORD and swings th BRIEFCASE into the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Mr. Butterfly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK tenses as MATHILDE raises her hand in farewell. The FORD pulls away and disappears down the slip road ont the autostrada. JACK watches it go. Thumbs back the lever on his Walther. Gets into his Citroen. And opens the ENVELOPE. -No wires. -No tricks. -Just a HUNDRED THOUSAND US DOLLARS. JACK stares at the money. He isn't supposed to be alive. a while he stays put. He shuts his eyes in the sunshine a listens to the laughter of the teenage kids. To a girl calling: "Amore!" To the cicadas. To the distant rush of traffic on the autostrada.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. AUTOSTRADA- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK drives fast... ...turning off the highway beneath a sign for L'AQUILA.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. L'AQUILA- DAY
dialogues.text: At the end a small street, JACK parks his car like a true Italian: illegally. Runs towards CLARA'S APARTMENT. And rings the buzzer. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK rings again. Still nothing. Shouts up at her window:

dialogues.speaker: EXT. AUTOSTRADA, CAFE- DAY
dialogues.text: We're at another roadside service station. LARRY comes out of a Kentucky Fried Chicken. He climbs into the passenger seat of the FORD. MATHILDE drives off.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FORD- DAY
dialogues.text: LARRY is dusting bread crumbs off his shirt. He's about to get his hands dirty and he doesn't like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not only did you not kill him, you gave him my fucking money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else could I do? There were kids everywhere. Besides he's suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's paranoid. That's why I'm paying you the GDP of a small country to get close to him. You could have got him in the sack. You should have got him in the car park. Now you're going to have to take him out long range!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I prefer it that way. She is a trained assassin. She respects JACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Socimi is the perfect weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hope his workmanship is up to scratch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams a full magazine into the butt of a STERLING SUBMACHINE GUN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweden turned Jack into a liability. Three stiffs: two shooters and an innocent civilian. I can't afford a mistake like that again. Europol are crooked but they aren't cheap. Jack's supposed to make me money. Not run up cleaning bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He made short work of the last guy you hired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind Larson. He didn't stand a chance, not against someone as paranoid as Jack. The Swede was only there to take Jack's heat off you. So don't fuck this up again. He grabs a TIN of fruit sweets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I help myself? LARRY opens the tin to find it full of AMMUNITION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. He looks around the Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any actual candy in this gas guzzler?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. AUTOSTRADA- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK turns off under the sign for CASTEL DEL MONTE.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, CHURCH STEPS- DAY
dialogues.text: The town square is jam-packed with cars and coaches. Hundreds of tourists and locals have gathered on the chur steps. There is even a camera crew. The church doors open and FATHER BENEDETTO steps out to a huge cheer. Behind him, LOCAL MEN are carrying a larger than life pai wooden STATUE OF SAINT DOMINIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Draped over the saint's shoulder and wrapped around his n are around twenty five or thirty live SNAKES- local Viper each one several feet long and as thick as a skinny forea A local BAND strikes up as the STATUE is carried down the steps, FATHER BENEDETTO leading the strange annual religi parade around the town square, followed by a group of ALT BOYS.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, STREET- DAY
dialogues.text: The giant FORD pulls up outside the town's only proper HO MATHILDE gets out carrying the SAMSONITE BRIEFCASE.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CASTEL DEL MONTE, TOWN SQUARE- DAY
dialogues.text: JACK is looking for someone. The square is so tightly pac it's hard to see, let alone move. Then he spots her. CLARA. She's on the other side of the square, standing on the st steps beneath a STATUE OF AN EAGLE. Her friend ANNA is be her, taking photographs of the parade with a small digita camera. JACK moves towards CLARA. ANNA, through her viewfinder, is the first to notice him. points JACK out to CLARA. CLARA waves at him. She says something to ANNA and descends into the crowd. JACK and C squeeze their way through a sea of bodies towards one ano as we cut to...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOTEL ROOF- DAY
dialogues.text: MATHILDE emerges through the fire escape door and walks t the edge of the roof. She opens the black SAMSONITE CASE and unpacks the top la of office paraphernalia to reveal the disassembled parts the SOCIMI SUBMACHINE GUN. Expertly she assembles the bastardised gun- including TELESCOPIC SIGHTS and SOUND SUPPRESSOR- slotting a full magazine into the base of the hand grip, snuggling the bu to her shoulder and placing her eye beside the rubber cup the sight.

dialogues.speaker: TELESCOPIC SIGHTS- DAY
dialogues.text: In the centre of the CROSS-HAIRS:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK and CLARA meet. She kisses him. It is a long and loving kiss. The CROSS-HAIRS find the centre of JACK's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATHILDE'S FINGER... taking up the trigger slack.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TELESCOPIC SIGHTS- DAY
dialogues.text: Other HEADS...

dialogues.speaker: -LOCALS
dialogues.text: -KIDS on their PARENTS' SHOULDERS ...keep blocking our view of JACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TRIGGER FINGER, hesitating.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TOWN SQUARE- DAY
dialogues.text: We're right in the midst of the crowd. JACK and CLARA have to shout at one another above the noi of the band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When can I see you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to work tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their happiness clouds over. But the clouds pass quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come to my apartment after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I asked you would you come away with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come away with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wherever. Then when we're through, we could come back here. For good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forever?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forever. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
